This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants in a theory-of-mind task contrasting deception vs cooperation. It directly probes social processing (understanding others' intentions/expectations), is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is not a between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants (n=13) performing a ToM task that explicitly manipulates cooperation vs deception — a social communication paradigm (cooperation/deception listed as example tasks). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (DEC>COOP), the contrast indexes theory-of-mind reasoning about other protagonists' intentions (deception vs cooperation). The 'perception_self' construct targets self-related processes (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency). This analysis reflects attribution about others rather than perception/understanding of the self, so it should be excluded.

DEC>COOP is a within-group, voxelwise task contrast from healthy adult participants (n=13) contrasting deception vs cooperation in a theory-of-mind task. This is a whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrast probing understanding of others' mental states, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study used a cooperation/deception ToM task in healthy adults and reports whole-brain group contrasts, the specific contrast provided (DEC > COOP) isolates deception-related activity relative to cooperation. Inclusion requires contrasts that measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., cooperation or loved‑one > stranger); DEC>COOP does not index affiliation/attachment and therefore should be excluded.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast from healthy adult volunteers probing theory-of-mind/social processing (cooperation vs deception), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group comparison, so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants; group-level voxelwise contrasts of a ToM task (cooperation, deception, combined) reported across the whole brain; the task includes a cooperation condition relevant to affiliation/attachment (cooperation vs others). Analysis is not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants examining cooperation/deception (theory-of-mind) interactions — a social communication task (cooperation/deception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast from healthy adult volunteers (ToM task contrasting cooperation/deception conditions) that probes understanding of others' mental states (theory-of-mind). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and thus fits the perception_others inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes theory-of-mind about other agents (intentions/expectations in cooperation vs deception). It does not measure self-related processes (self-awareness, self-knowledge or agency), so it does not meet the Perception/Understanding of Self inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social task (deception vs cooperation). It is whole-brain, not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and directly measures social processing (ToM/understanding others), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast in healthy adult participants comparing deception and cooperation/deception conditions from a ToM task. The task probes social interactions (cooperation/deception), which fits the Social Communication construct, and the analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind task probing cooperation/deception — a direct measure of Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding mental states). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study used a ToM task that included cooperation, this specific contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) indexes deception-related processing (deception greater than cooperation/deception) rather than affiliation/attachment. The inclusion rules require the contrast itself to measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., cooperation > other), so this analysis should be excluded.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain group-level comparison in healthy adults and the task involves social interactions (cooperation/deception), it addresses theory-of-mind reasoning about other agents' intentions/expectations (processing others) rather than Perception and Understanding of the Self (self-awareness, self-monitoring, or self-knowledge). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the 'perception_self' annotation.

This is a within-group, task-evoked, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social task (cooperation/deception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from a healthy adult sample studying cooperation/deception in a ToM task. The task measures social interaction/communication (cooperation vs deception), and the analysis is a whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Healthy adult sample (n=13) and this is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from a ToM paradigm that isolates cooperation (affiliation) versus deception. The task involves cooperation-related social interaction (an affiliation construct), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from a healthy adult sample (n=13) using a Theory-of-Mind paradigm about others' intentions (cooperation/deception). The task measures understanding of others' mental states (Perception and Understanding of Others), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social task (cooperation vs. deception conditions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (healthy volunteers), group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) reported in table (n=13, voxelwise thresholding), task involves cooperation/deception (explicitly listed as an example task under the Perception/Understanding of Self category—cooperation/competition), and this is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate task contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult volunteers (n=13) using a cooperation/deception ToM paradigm. The task directly assesses social interaction/communication (cooperation vs deception), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the task includes cooperation, the reported contrast (COOPDEC > COOP) isolates deception-related processing (cooperation/deception vs cooperation) rather than a pure affiliation/attachment comparison. The contrast does not directly index affiliative bonding or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or cooperative vs non-cooperative social bonding), so it fails the requirement that the contrast measure affiliation/attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from a task explicitly probing theory-of-mind / understanding others (cooperation vs deception) in healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the COOPDEC>COOP contrast indexes reasoning about other agents' intentions (theory-of-mind about protagonists—cooperation/deception) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the participant's own mental states. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind/social interaction task (cooperation vs deception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOP>DEC) in healthy adult participants (n=13) from a task that explicitly manipulates cooperation versus deception. Cooperation maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (example task listed: Cooperation), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate task contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy adult subjects probing cooperation vs deception in a theory-of-mind/social interaction paradigm. Cooperation is an example of social communication, and the contrast is neither ROI-based nor connectivity or between-group, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, univariate whole-brain task contrast (COOP>DEC) in healthy adult participants from a ToM task assessing reasoning about others' intentions (cooperation vs deception). It directly probes 'Understanding Mental States' and meets the sample and analysis inclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group contrast).

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy adult volunteers (n=13) using a theory-of-mind/social interaction task, and therefore measures social processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults (COOP>DEC), the task contrasts reasoning about other characters' intentions (cooperation vs deception) — a theory-of-mind/other-focused social cognition contrast — rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (n=13) comparing cooperation vs cooperation/deception. The task explicitly probes cooperative social interactions (affiliation), fits the example tasks (cooperation), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The COOP>COOPDEC contrast is a within-group, task-evoked, whole-brain (voxelwise) univariate comparison from healthy adult participants (n=13) probing cooperation vs cooperation/deception in a ToM paradigm. The task directly measures social communication (cooperation), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy volunteers in a ToM paradigm probing cooperation vs cooperation/deception. It is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (per table caption) and directly measures perception/understanding of others' intentions, so it meets the inclusion criteria (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis).

Although the analysis is a healthy adult, whole-brain within-group contrast (COOP>COOPDEC), the task probes theory-of-mind reasoning about protagonists' intentions/expectations (others) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. The contrast therefore does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This is a group-level main effect of viewing eyes in a healthy adult sample and probes social processing (pupillary/eye cues). Although the table notes FFA ROI coordinates for reference, the contrast is reported as a whole-brain task-evoked effect (not an ROI-only connectivity or between-group analysis), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, task-evoked fMRI study of social eye/pupil processing, the contrast ('main effect of viewing eyes' / pupillary coherence) indexes social salience/attention rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation, bonding). The table also references an ROI (FFA), so it may not represent a pure whole-brain affiliation/attachment contrast. Therefore it does not meet the "affiliation_attachment" inclusion criteria.

This analysis does not meet the 'perception_self' criteria. It probes perception of others' eye/pupil signals and social salience rather than awareness or judgments about the self, and the table text refers to a fusiform face area ROI (ROI-based reporting) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain main-effect contrast (viewing eyes/changes in observed vs observer pupil size) in a healthy adult sample. The task probes perception of another's pupil dynamics (a social cue), so it measures social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked main effect (viewing eyes) in a healthy adult sample measuring reception of facial/social signals (pupillary/eye cues), which fits the Social Communication construct. Although the table notes an FFA ROI coordinate for reference, the contrast reported is a whole‑brain main effect (voxelwise activations in STS, amygdala, etc.), so it meets the whole‑brain, univariate inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group analysis on healthy adults, the task probes pupillary mirroring and social salience rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, bonding). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain main-effect of viewing dynamic pupils in 14 healthy subjects and indexes perception of socially relevant facial/eye signals (pupillary exchange), fitting the 'reception of facial communication' subconstruct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level main effect of viewing others' eyes/pupillary signals in healthy adult participants, which targets perception of social signals (Perception and Understanding of Others). It reports task-evoked activation (e.g., fusiform, STS, amygdala) rather than connectivity or between-group contrasts. Although an FFA coordinate is noted as an ROI reference, the contrast is presented as a whole-brain main effect and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adults assessing coherence/discordance between observed pupils and the participant's own pupil responses. The contrast indexes self-monitoring/self-awareness of internal (autonomic) state in a social context, fitting the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

Healthy adult sample (n=14) and reported group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (main effect of viewing eyes / change in observed vs observer pupil size). The task involves perception of another's eyes/pupil dynamics — a social signal used to infer others' internal/dispositional state — which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

The analysis is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (labelled 'Region of interest analysis'), which violates the inclusion requirement for a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. Although the task is social and participants appear to be healthy adults, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (labelled "Region of interest analysis"), whereas the inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. In addition, the task probes pupillary exchange/social salience rather than a canonical affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not clearly measure the specified affiliation/attachment construct.

The analysis is explicitly a Region-of-Interest (ROI) analysis (not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map). ROI analyses are listed in the exclusion criteria, so it does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement despite the task involving eye/face processing in healthy adults.

The analysis is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (Table/analysis labelled 'Region of interest analysis'), which violates the exclusion criterion requiring group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps. Although the sample (healthy adults) and task (viewing others' eyes/pupil dynamics) are relevant, the ROI approach disqualifies it.

This analysis is an ROI analysis (not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map) and thus fails the 'whole-brain evidence' requirement. In addition, the contrast examines viewing others' eyes/pupil dynamics (social salience), not a task measuring perception/understanding of the self. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The analysis is labeled as "Regions of interest" (ROI) and thus is not a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise map. Although the task is social (viewing eyes/pupillary exchange) and participants are healthy adults, ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so this analysis should not be included.

This is an ROI analysis (labelled 'Regions of interest') of pupil-feedback interaction rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast measuring affiliation/attachment. The task manipulates pupillary coherence/social salience, not an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation), so it fails the whole-brain and task-domain inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis is from a 'Regions of interest' section (ROI-based), not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task map as required. Although the task involves viewing eyes (social/facial communication) and healthy adults, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

The analysis is reported under “Regions of interest” and describes an interaction (feedback × pupil variance) derived from ROI measures rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, univariate, group-level maps in healthy adults; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adult participants probing responses to viewing eyes and pupillary feedback (a social signal). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the whole-brain, social-processing inclusion criteria.

The analysis is an ROI-based result (labelled "Regions of interest"), and the inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain univariate (voxelwise) map. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Additionally, although the study probes self–other pupillary coherence, the contrast does not clearly map onto the Perception/Understanding of Self construct as defined.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports group-level task activations, the contrast (positive > negative; interaction of feedback condition with pupil variance) indexes pupillary mirroring and social salience rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved‑one vs stranger). It does not measure affiliation or attachment per the inclusion criteria, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adults comparing positively- vs negatively-correlated pupillary feedback while viewing eyes. It indexes reception of socially relevant facial/eye signals (pupillary communication), is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is not a between-group contrast, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (positive > negative) indexes coherence/discordance between observed and observed participants' pupil changes (social salience/peer physiological mirroring). It does not probe self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the self required for the 'perception_self' construct, so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

This is a within-subject, whole-brain group contrast (positive > negative) from healthy adult participants examining responses to viewing others' eyes / pupillary dynamics (social perceptual signals). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and pertains to perception of others' states/salience, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The analysis is labeled as "Regions of interest," indicating an ROI-based analysis rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map. Although the task (viewing eyes / pupillary social signals) is social and the sample appears to be healthy adults, ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so this analysis should not be included.

The analysis is labeled as "Regions of interest," indicating an ROI-based analysis rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise map required by the inclusion criteria. Although the task (viewing eyes/pupillary exchange) targets social signals, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is an ROI analysis (table/analysis labelled 'Regions of interest') rather than a group-level whole‑brain voxelwise map. The inclusion criteria require whole‑brain univariate task-evoked maps; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Therefore it should not be annotated as 'perception_self'.

Exclude — this is an ROI analysis (not a whole‑brain voxelwise group map) and the task probes pupillary coherence/social salience rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (no contrast like loved one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation).

This is an ROI analysis (labelled "Regions of interest" and describing an interaction between feedback condition and pupil variance) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise univariate map. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This analysis characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC responses during face/object individuation and appears to be an ROI-based characterization (faces vs non-face stimuli), not a whole-brain group-level univariate map of an affiliation/attachment task. The task does not measure affiliation/attachment (social bonding) and the analysis is ROI-focused, so it fails the task and whole-brain inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a region-of-interest characterization (FFA, OFA, LOC) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain voxelwise evidence; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Although the task involves face individuation in healthy adults (a social-related process), the ROI nature of the analysis disqualifies it.

This analysis is a region-of-interest (FFA/OFA/LOC) characterization rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrast. Although the study involves face individuation (facial recognition), it fails the inclusion requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps and thus meets the ROI exclusion criterion.

This analysis does not meet the 'perception_self' criteria. It characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC responses during face/object individuation (identity discrimination of others/objects), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. In addition the table/analysis focuses on region-of-interest characterization rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast, and ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

The reported analysis is an ROI characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC (table caption: characterization of regions of interest). The inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise map; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Although the task involves face individuation (a social-related stimulus), this entry is an ROI analysis and therefore does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement.

This analysis is an ROI-based characterization of face/object-selective regions (FFA, OFA, LOC) using an identity/individuation task. It does not probe Perception and Understanding of Others (mental states, social relations, action/animacy perception) as defined by the annotation, and it is reported as ROI-based rather than a whole-brain, group-level univariate map. Both factors make it ineligible.

This analysis examines face/object individuation and ROI characterization (FFA/OFA/LOC) rather than an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger). It does not measure affiliation/attachment processes and appears ROI-focused, so it fails the task/content and analysis-type inclusion criteria.

This analysis is ROI-based (characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC and ROI-defined contrast face>non-face) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task map, which violates the whole-brain inclusion requirement. In addition, the task is identity/individuation of faces/objects (not an explicit social-communication contrast), so it does not meet the intended social_communication task criteria.

This analysis characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC ROIs and reports responses to face/object individuation (faces, objects, watches) — not tasks about perception/understanding of the self. It also appears to be ROI-based (and not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise contrast). Thus it fails the task-domain requirement (self-related processing) and the whole-brain inclusion criterion.

This analysis examines face/object individuation and ROI characterization (FFA, OFA, LOC) rather than an affiliation/attachment task. It is not a task contrast measuring social affiliation (e.g., loved one vs stranger) and appears to involve ROI/localizer contrasts rather than a whole‑brain group-level univariate map relevant to attachment. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis is presented as characterization of predefined ROIs (FFA, OFA, LOC) and the table caption/description indicates ROI-based contrasts (e.g., faces > objects). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise map; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded. Although face individuation relates to social perception, the analysis fails the whole-brain requirement and is therefore excluded.

This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. It reports ROI-based characterization (FFA/OFA/LOC) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task map, and the task (individuation of faces/objects) probes identity discrimination rather than Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., emotional states, traits, or mental-state inference).

This analysis is an ROI characterization (FFA/OFA/LOC defined via a faces > non-face passive viewing contrast) and addresses face/object individuation, not Perception/Understanding of the self. It is not a whole-brain group-level, task-evoked map measuring self-related processing, and ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This analysis does not meet the "perception_others" criteria. The task is an identity/individuation discrimination of faces and objects (not assessing others' emotions, traits, intentions or similar social/mental-state constructs), and the table/description indicates ROI-based characterization of FFA/OFA rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrast. Both the task content and the ROI analysis approach violate the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC ROIs (ROI-based), not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. Although the task involves face individuation (a social stimulus), ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

This analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment. It reports face/object individuation and ROI characterization (FFA/OFA/LOC) from a face/object perception task, not a task about social bonding/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger). It also appears to involve ROI definitions rather than a whole-brain group-level univariate map, so it fails the task and whole-brain/ROI inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a face localizer (FACES > OBJECTS) used to define/characterize ROIs (FFA, OFA, LOC) per the table caption. That makes this an ROI-based/localizer analysis rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task map generalizable to healthy adults. ROI analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included despite involving face perception.

This entry reports ROI characterization/localizer (FFA, OFA, LOC defined by faces > non-face) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, univariate group maps; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This table/analysis is an ROI characterization (FFA, OFA, LOC defined via a face > non-face localizer and subsequent ROI responses), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise map. Although the task involves face individuation (a social stimulus), the analysis is ROI-based and therefore excluded under the criteria requiring whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps.

This analysis is not a whole‑brain, group-level task contrast measuring self-perception. It focuses on ROI characterization (FFA, OFA, LOC) and object/face individuation (identity discrimination), not on Perception and Understanding of the Self. Additionally, ROI-based analyses are excluded by the criteria.

This analysis characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC (ROI-based) responses to face/object individuation. It is not a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast measuring "Perception and Understanding of Others" (e.g., mental state, animacy, action perception or social scenarios). Moreover, the table describes ROI definitions/analyses (excluded by criteria). Therefore it should not be included.

This analysis tests perceptual individuation of faces and objects (FFA/OFA/LOC characterization), not measures of affiliation or attachment (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). It is also an ROI/region characterization rather than a whole-brain, task-evoked contrast targeting social bonding, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This analysis investigates individuation of faces/objects (face vs object processing and ROI characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC) in healthy adults, not Perception and Understanding of the Self. It also appears to report ROI-based characterizations rather than a group-level whole-brain task contrast targeting self-related processes, so it fails the content and method inclusion criteria.

Although the task (face individuation) maps onto Reception of Facial Communication (facial recognition), the reported analysis is a characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC regions of interest rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. ROI-based analyses are explicitly excluded by the inclusion criteria, so this analysis should not be included.

This analysis is a characterization of predefined ROIs (FFA, OFA, LOC) derived from a localizer/passive-viewing task and reports ROI responses rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. Although the task involves faces (a social stimulus) and participants are healthy adults, it fails the whole-brain / univariate voxelwise inclusion criterion and falls under the ROI-analysis exclusion.

The analysis concerns individuation of faces/objects and characterization of FFA/OFA/LOC (ROI-based) rather than any affiliation/attachment task (e.g., loved one vs stranger). It is not a whole-brain group-level univariate map measuring affiliation/attachment and is explicitly an ROI analysis, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This analysis characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC using a face > non-face localizer and ROI-based analyses for identity discrimination of faces/objects. It is not a whole-brain, group-level univariate map targeting Perception/Understanding of Others (e.g., animacy, action perception, or mental-state inference), and it appears to be ROI-based rather than the required voxelwise whole-brain contrast. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is an ROI characterization (FFA, OFA, LOC) rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrast. Although the task involves face perception (which relates to facial reception), ROI-based analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included.

This analysis does not measure Perception/Understanding of the self — it tests individuation of faces and objects (identity discrimination), not self-related judgments. In addition, the table/analysis characterizes FFA/OFA/LOC ROIs rather than reporting a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast, so it fails both the task-domain and whole-brain/ROI criteria.

This analysis does not meet the 'perception_others' criteria. The task is identity/individuation of faces and objects (not assessing others' mental states, actions, or animacy) and the table describes characterization of ROIs (FFA/OFA/LOC), indicating ROI-based analyses rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

Exclude. The analysis is an ROI characterization (FFA/OFA/LOC), not a group-level whole-brain univariate task map, and the task (identity/individuation of faces and objects) does not measure affiliation or attachment/social bond processes.

This analysis characterizes FFA, OFA, and LOC regions of interest (ROI-based) rather than reporting a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. Although the task (face individuation) is social-relevant, it fails the whole-brain/univariate map inclusion criterion and therefore must be excluded.

The reported analysis is a characterization of FFA, OFA, and LOC regions of interest (ROI-based). Although the task (face individuation/identity discrimination) relates to facial recognition, the inclusion rules require a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked map. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. The table/analysis characterizes FFA, OFA, and LOC via ROI-based contrasts (not a group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task map), and the task contrasts concern individuation of faces/objects (identity discrimination), not Perception and Understanding of the Self. Therefore it fails both the task-domain and whole-brain/ROI requirements.

This is a whole-brain, random-effects group contrast (social interaction vs non-social interaction) from a task that probes social perception/interaction in (presumably) healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. The reported results are ROI-based (FFA/OFA/LOC characterization and ROI responses) rather than a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast, and the task probes identity individuation of faces/objects rather than Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., animacy, action perception, or mental-state/social inference). Therefore it fails the whole-brain and task-domain requirements.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in (presumably) healthy adults (social interaction vs non‑interaction), the task probes detection of generic social interactions between agents rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/parental bonding). Therefore it does not meet the content-specific inclusion criterion for affiliation_attachment.

This is a whole-brain random-effects group contrast (social interaction vs non-social interaction) in a healthy adult sample, indexing perception/understanding of others (observing interactions/agent actions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, random-effects group contrast (social interaction vs non-social interaction) in healthy adults that indexes perception of interactions conveyed by body motion (receptive non-facial social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (observing social interactions vs non-social displays) targets perception/understanding of others' interactions (social/mentalizing and mirror networks), not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

This entry describes regions-of-interest (MNI coordinates and ROI volumes) used for real-time pattern classification. It is an ROI-based / multivariate real-time analysis rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast required by the inclusion criteria, so it must be excluded.

This entry reports regions-of-interest used for real-time pattern classification (ROI coordinates and volumes), not a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise statistical map. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain group-level contrasts in healthy adults; ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This entry lists region-of-interest (ROI) coordinates/volumes used for real-time classification rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. Per the inclusion criteria, ROI analyses are excluded (requires univariate whole-brain maps), so this analysis should not be included.

This entry reports regions-of-interest (ROI) center coordinates and volumes used for real-time classification (ROI-based/multivariate approach), not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast measuring self-perception. ROI/real-time classification analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria.

This entry reports ROI centre coordinates/volumes used for real-time classification (ROI-based analysis), not a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. It therefore fails the whole-brain/univariate inclusion criterion and matches the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses.

This entry reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (offline MVPA) and a table of ROIs (weight maps thresholded/clusters), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast. The inclusion criteria require a voxelwise univariate group map generalizable to healthy adults; MVPA/ROI-based results do not meet that requirement.

This is an MVPA/SVM offline classification reporting discriminative volumes/ROIs (weight maps thresholded) rather than a group-level univariate, voxelwise task contrast. It therefore does not meet the whole‑brain univariate requirement (and reads as ROI/MVPA-based), so it should be excluded.

This is an ROI-based, real-time multivariate classification (regions of interest used for classifying 70:30 vs 80:20 offers) rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. It therefore fails the whole-brain/univariate inclusion criterion (ROI/multivariate classification analyses are excluded).

This entry reports discriminating volumes from a linear SVM (multivariate classification) and lists ROIs/thresholded classifier weights used for real-time classification. It is not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise statistical map and effectively represents MVPA/ROI-based results, so it fails the whole-brain univariate inclusion criterion and meets the ROI/multivariate exclusion criteria.

This is a multivariate SVM classification (discriminative volumes / ROIs) rather than a group-level univariate whole‑brain task contrast. The result reflects classifier weights/ROI-based discriminative voxels for predicting decisions, so it does not meet the requirement for a voxelwise univariate group statistical map.

This analysis reports discriminative volumes from a linear SVM (offline MVPA) / ROIs used for real-time classification rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map. The inclusion criteria require voxelwise univariate group maps from healthy adults; MVPA/classifier/ROI results do not meet that requirement.

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time pattern classification of offer types (70:30 vs 80:20) in an ultimatum game. It is not a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast and instead uses ROI/multivariate classification of financial offers (objective incentives) rather than an affiliation/attachment contrast. Thus it fails the whole-brain (and task/contrast) inclusion criteria.

This analysis describes regions of interest used for real-time pattern classification (ROI/multivariate classification of offer types in the ultimatum game). Inclusion requires a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task map in healthy adults. ROI/multivariate classification analyses do not meet the whole-brain univariate requirement, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time pattern classification (70:30 vs 80:20 offers) from an ultimatum-game study, not a group-level whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. The inclusion criteria require healthy adult, whole-brain univariate maps measuring perception/understanding of others; ROI/MVPA/classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is an ROI-based multivariate real-time classification (predicting offer type/decisions in the ultimatum game), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrast. The analysis therefore fails the whole-brain/univariate inclusion requirement (and ROI/MVPA analyses are listed in the exclusion criteria).

This analysis is an ROI-based real-time/multivariate classification (50:50 vs 65:35 offers) from an ultimatum-game task. Although the task is social, the result is not a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise contrast generalizable to healthy adults. It is an ROI/multivariate classification (real-time) rather than the required whole-brain task-evoked group map, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This analysis describes ROI-based real-time/multivariate classification (regions of interest used to classify 50:50 vs 65:35 offers) rather than a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, group-level univariate maps; ROI/multivariate classification analyses are explicitly excluded.

This analysis is an ROI-based / online multivariate classification (50:50 vs 65:35 offers) from an ultimatum-game study, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain, voxelwise univariate maps measuring affiliation/attachment; ROI/MVPA and online classification analyses are excluded.

Although the task (ultimatum game) involves social interaction, this entry describes ROI-based real-time multivariate classification of offer types rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrast. The analysis is ROI/multivariate (classification) and thus fails the whole-brain, univariate inclusion criterion.

Excluded because this analysis used Regions of Interest and real-time pattern classification (MVPA) rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. Although the task is social (ultimatum game with offers), it does not meet the whole-brain univariate inclusion requirement and ROI/classification analyses are specifically excluded.

The contrast examines emotional prosody (simple/complex emotion vs neutral) rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate contrast (emotional prosody trials > neutral) reporting MNI peaks at p<0.05 corrected. The task is emotional prosody comprehension (social communication / perception of others' emotions), conducted in healthy adults (no clinical group or between-group comparison). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analysis, so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain contrast (emotional prosody > neutral) indexing comprehension of emotional tone of voice, i.e. reception of non-facial social communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and the study concerns healthy adult participants, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional prosody: simple/complex emotion > neutral) measuring perception/understanding of others' emotional states (emotional prosody comprehension). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and (per study context) involves healthy adult participants, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotion) from an emotional prosody task that probes perception/understanding of others' emotions — a social-processing construct. The report lists whole-brain local maxima and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and the study context indicates a healthy adult sample, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This contrast reflects emotional prosody comprehension (complex vs. simple emotion) rather than an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although it appears to be a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure affiliation or attachment processes as defined by the inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares perception of complex versus simple emotions in others' prosody (emotional prosody comprehension), which indexes social perception of others' emotional states rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a healthy-group, whole-brain task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody) reporting MNI local maxima and corrected statistics in a study of emotional prosody comprehension in healthy adults. Emotional prosody comprehension is reception of non-facial social communication (affect recognition via voice), so the contrast measures Social Communication and meets the inclusion (and not the exclusion) criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody) reporting MNI local maxima and corrected p-values in a healthy adult sample. The task measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states (emotional prosody, requiring socio-cognitive/mental-state attribution), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast indexes perception of emotional prosody (processing others' emotions) versus neutral tone, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or social comparisons about the self. Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined, so it should be excluded.

This contrast probes emotional prosody (complex vs simple emotions) and not measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a healthy, whole-brain group contrast, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (complex > simple emotion, controlled for pitch) indexing emotional prosody comprehension — a social processing task (recognizing others' emotions). It is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group comparison, and the study context indicates healthy adult participants, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes emotional prosody comprehension (distinguishing complex vs simple emotions in others' voices), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although likely a healthy-group, whole-brain contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required by the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody, pitch-controlled) indexing comprehension of others' emotions from tone of voice—a clear Perception/Understanding of Others task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and is reported as group-level activation peaks; therefore it meets the inclusion criteria. (Assumes participants are healthy adults as implied by the study context.)

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain contrast (complex vs. simple emotional prosody, pitch-controlled) reporting corrected peaks in MNI space. The task probes reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody) in healthy adults and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, within-subject task-evoked contrast from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using a self/other referential (social) task (VV-SORP-T). This is not an ROI or connectivity analysis and targets self-referential social processing, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is from a self-referential / self-esteem task (self vs fixation) rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although it is a whole‑brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it does not probe social attachment or close-relationship processes required by the 'affiliation_attachment' inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, task-evoked fMRI contrast from a healthy adult sample (20 women) probing self-referential processing (viewing/self-rehearsal of self vs baseline). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level task-evoked within-subject/univariate contrast (S > fixation) from a sample of healthy adult women (not a clinical group), and is not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task (Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing) involves viewing faces (self vs other) and attributing trait adjectives, which fits the 'Reception of Facial Communication' subconstruct of Social Communication (facial recognition/characterization). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (S‑P > Fixation) from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using the Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing Task, which probes self‑referential/social processing. It is a group-level univariate contrast (not ROI or connectivity) measuring social processing (perception/understanding of self), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is S-N > Fixation from a self/other referential task; S-N corresponds to a self-referential (self negative) trial versus baseline. Although the study includes other‑referent conditions, this specific analysis indexes self-processing rather than perception/understanding of others, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion criterion.

The contrast (S‑P > Fixation) reflects self‑referential/valenced self‑esteem processing (self vs baseline) in a VV self/other task, not an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although the sample is healthy and this is a group-level contrast, it does not measure social bonding/attachment per the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject univariate task contrast from a healthy adult sample (20 women) drawn from a self-referential task (Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing). S-P > Fixation reflects self-related trial activity (likely self-positive trials) versus baseline, which indexes perception/understanding of the self. It is not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

This is a group-level, within-subject univariate task contrast (O-P > fixation) from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using a self/other referential task. The task probes social processing (self- and other-referential/social cognition), and the contrast appears to be a whole-brain task-evoked map rather than an ROI/ connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain contrast in a healthy adult sample, the contrast (S‑P > Fixation) indexes self-referential/valenced self-esteem processing rather than a social-communication contrast. It does not probe exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals (e.g., self vs other, loved one vs stranger, facial communication) as required by the social_communication annotation, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in a healthy adult sample, the contrast (Other Positive > Fixation) comes from a valenced self-/other-referential/self-esteem task. It does not probe affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation) or measure bonding/attachment-related processes, so it does not meet the task-domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast 'S-P > Fixation' refers to self-referential (self, positive) trials versus fixation, not to perception or understanding of others. Although the task includes other-person trials, this specific analysis indexes self-processing rather than representation or reasoning about others, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults (20 women). The VV-SORP-T task involves viewing faces (self/other) and attributing valenced traits, which constitutes reception/processing of socially relevant facial and trait information (analogous to contrasts like loved one vs stranger). The contrast O-P > Fixation therefore indexes social processing and meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast O-P > Fixation indexes activity for 'Other' (other-positive) trials, not self-referential processing. Although the study uses a self/other referential task and the sample is healthy and this is a group-level task contrast, the contrast does not measure Perception/Understanding of the self, so it fails the core inclusion criterion.

O-P > Fixation appears to be the Other (positive trait) > fixation within the VV-SORP-T self/other referential task in a healthy adult sample. This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast probing processing of others’ traits (Perception/Understanding of Others), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, group-level univariate contrast (O-N > Fixation) from a task that explicitly manipulates self- vs other-referential processing (social cognition). The sample is healthy adult women and the contrast appears to be a whole-brain task-evoked map (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, within‑group contrast in healthy adults, the VV‑SORP‑T task probes self/other referential processing and valenced self‑esteem, not affiliation/attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, or attachment measures). The O‑N > Fixation contrast (other/negative vs baseline) does not index affiliation or attachment processes, so it fails the task/contrast inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, within-subject univariate contrast (Other trials > fixation) from a healthy adult sample viewing unknown other women and associating trait adjectives (i.e., judgments about others). That matches the Perception/Understanding of Others construct and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group comparison).

The contrast O-N > Fixation reflects processing of an 'Other' trial relative to baseline rather than self-referential processing. The inclusion criteria require contrasts that measure Perception and Understanding of the Self (e.g., self vs other); this contrast does not index self-related perception, so it should be excluded.

Although the contrast is a group-level task activation in healthy adults, the VV-SORP-T targets valenced self‑referential processing (self vs other trait attribution/self‑esteem), not an exchange or communicative processing of social signals. Viewing faces and rating traits is self‑referential/social-cognitive rather than measuring Social Communication (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communication, cooperation/competition, or social comparison as defined). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's Social_Communication inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, group-level contrast (S-N > S-P) from a task that manipulates self-referential, valenced social processing (Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing) in a healthy adult sample. It is a task-evoked univariate contrast comparing trial types (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis) and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults (self-negative > self-positive), the task probes valenced self-referential / self-esteem processing rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., no loved-one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation, or attachment measures). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment content criterion.

This is a within‑group, group‑level contrast from the Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing Task in a healthy adult sample (healthy women). The S‑N > S‑P contrast compares valenced self‑referential conditions (self negative vs self positive), which directly probes perception/understanding of the self (self‑knowledge/self‑evaluation). It is not a ROI, connectivity, resting‑state, or between‑group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

S-N > S-P contrasts valenced self-referential processing (likely Self–Negative > Self–Positive). It does not measure perception/understanding of others (e.g., other vs self or other-related judgments), so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion for "perception_others."

The contrast S-N > S-P indexes valenced self-referential processing (self negative vs self positive) from a self-esteem task, not an exchange or reception/production of socially communicative signals. Although it is a group-level task contrast in healthy adults, it does not target Social Communication (e.g., self vs other, social comparison, or receipt/production of facial/non‑facial communicative cues), so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (self-positive > self-negative) from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using a self/other referential processing task—i.e., self-referential social processing. It is a group-level univariate contrast between trial types (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast from healthy adult participants (self trials with positive vs negative trait adjectives: S-P > S-N) from the Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task, targeting self-referential/self-knowledge processes. The table caption describes group-level trial-type differences (implying a whole-brain univariate contrast) and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the perception_self inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (S-P > S-N likely Self‑Positive > Self‑Negative), the task probes valenced self‑referential processing/self‑esteem rather than affiliation or attachment (social bonds, close relationships, attachment styles). It does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

The contrast S-P > S-N compares positive vs negative self-referential trials (valenced self-processing), not perception/understanding of others. Although the task includes 'other' trials, this specific analysis indexes self-referential valence rather than a 'perception of others' contrast, so it does not meet the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The contrast (S-P > S-N) indexes valenced self-referential processing (positive vs negative traits about the self) in a self-esteem task rather than a social-communication exchange (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or interpersonal comparisons). Although the task involves viewing faces, this analysis targets self‑referential valence, not a social-communication contrast, so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast S-N > O-N reflects a task-evoked, group-level comparison of self- versus other-referential processing (valenced SRP) in healthy adult participants (20 women). This is a whole-brain, univariate task contrast relevant to perception/understanding of self and others (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (self vs other valenced trait evaluation), the task probes valenced self-referential processing / self-esteem with unknown others rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, bonding, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment task domain and should be excluded.

This is a within-group, voxelwise group-level contrast (S-N > O-N) from a task that explicitly compares self versus other referential processing in healthy adult participants (women). It targets self-perception/knowledge (self vs other trait attribution) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast (S-N > O-N) in a sample of healthy adult women using a self vs other referential task (Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing). The contrast indexes self/other (social comparison/self‑referential) processing and involves viewing faces/trait adjectives, fitting the Social Communication construct (reception/processing of socially relevant facial/non‑facial information). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (S-P > O-P) from a Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task in a healthy adult sample (20 women). It targets self- vs. other-referential processing (a social cognition/social-processing construct) and is reported as a group-level whole-brain contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level within-subject whole-brain contrast in a healthy sample, the contrast S-N > O-N indexes greater self-referential (self-negative) processing relative to other-negative processing. The target construct requires analyses that measure perception/understanding of others (e.g., Other > Self or other-focused contrasts). Because this contrast primarily isolates self- rather than other-processing, it does not meet the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain group contrast (likely Self‑Positive > Other‑Positive) from the Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing task, it probes self‑referential valenced processing/self‑esteem rather than affiliation or attachment (close relationships, bonding, kinship, cooperation). CSL>TIC is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing complex social laughter to tickling laughter in (presumably) healthy adults and indexes perception/decoding of others' social/emotional signals. The contrast (tickling laughter > complex social laughter) indexes perception of others' laughter types, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-monitoring. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (tickling laughter > complex social laughter) and the task (perception/evaluation of laughter types) do not target Affiliation/Attachment constructs or measures (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). This is a group-level task contrast (tickling laughter > complex social laughter) reporting differential hemodynamic activation during perception of laughter in a healthy adult sample. This is a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast (CAT>COU) from a healthy adult sample probing perception/evaluation of different laughter types — a social-communication/social-processing task (perception and interpretation of others' laughter). The contrast tests perception of different laughter types (complex social vs other laughter/tickling) and focuses on hemodynamic activation/connectivity related to acoustic and social-information processing, not on affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation).
