The contrast is a group-level main effect (OTHER > SELF) from a task in which participants processed feedback about others' character traits versus themselves. This is a univariate, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (not ROI or connectivity) on healthy adult participants and directly indexes perception/understanding of others (other-related feedback), so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast is a between-group interaction ((SELF > OTHER) × (GERMAN > CHINESE)) comparing cultural subgroups. The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions, so it should not be included despite involving social processing in healthy adults.

The reported contrast is a between-group interaction ((SELF > OTHER) × (GERMAN > CHINESE)), i.e. a cultural group comparison. The inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts/interactions; the annotation requires a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore this analysis should not be included.

The contrast is a group interaction ((SELF > OTHER) × (GERMAN > CHINESE)), i.e. a between-group/subgroup comparison. The inclusion rules explicitly exclude between-group contrasts or interactions, so this analysis should not be included despite being a social-feedback task with healthy adults.

The contrast is an interaction with cultural groups ((SELF > OTHER) × (GERMAN > CHINESE)), i.e. a between-group comparison. The exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions, so this analysis should not be included despite probing self vs other processing.

The reported analysis is a between-group interaction ((SELF > OTHER) × (GERMAN > CHINESE)). Exclusion criteria disallow between-group contrasts/interactions (subgroup vs subgroup), so it should not be included despite involving self/other feedback.

This is a group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) correlation of task-evoked activity (feedback onset Self > Other) with behavioral updates from healthy adult participants in a social feedback task (self/other trait ratings). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This contrast indexes brain responses to perceiving/evaluating types of others' laughter (explicit evaluation and bout counting), not processes of self-perception/self-knowledge (agency or self-judgment). Although likely a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (SELF > OTHER) in healthy adult participants measuring neural responses to social feedback during a real-life face-to-face interaction where participants updated self- and other-ratings. The task involves social learning/self–other comparison relevant to affiliation/attachment (social bonds/interaction), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI contrast (Feedback onset: Self > Other) in healthy adult participants, examining neural responses to social feedback about self versus other (i.e., social communication/social comparison). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise map correlating neural activity with behavioral updates for the contrast Self > Other at feedback onset — a within-subject task contrast probing self-related processing (self-knowledge/self-monitoring) in healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults in a social feedback task, the reported contrast (SELF > OTHER) isolates self-related activity rather than neural activity indexing perception/understanding of others. The inclusion criteria require contrasts that measure perception/understanding of others (e.g., other > control or direct other-related contrasts); a Self>Other contrast does not meet that requirement.

This is a within-subject, task-evoked contrast (SELF > OTHER) indexing processing of social feedback about self versus others—clearly a social-processing construct (perception/understanding of self and others). The result is reported as significant activations in feedback onsets (typical whole-brain voxelwise SPM-style table), not an ROI or connectivity analysis, nor a between-group contrast. The sample is healthy adults. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast (SELF > OTHER) from a healthy adult sample during a face-to-face social feedback task that involves social evaluation/updating (social comparison/learning), which fits the affiliation/attachment domain. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

The contrast (FEEDBACK RATING ... SELF > OTHER) is a within-subject, task-evoked activation reflecting processing of social feedback about self versus other during a face-to-face interaction. The sample comprises healthy adult participants, the table reports whole-brain activations (not an ROI or connectivity analysis), and the contrast indexes social-communication processing (exchange/reception of socially relevant information). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, task-evoked contrast (Self > Other) reflecting neural responses to self-related versus other-related feedback, reported as significant whole-brain activations in the table. The sample comprises healthy adult participants and the analysis is a group-level univariate voxelwise map (trial-by-trial parametric correlation), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Self construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a group-level task fMRI contrast indexing trial-by-trial feedback discrepancies for self and other during a social feedback task in healthy adult participants. The table reports whole-brain activation results (not ROI or connectivity) and the task directly measures social processing (self/other feedback), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample comparing neural responses to feedback about the self versus another person in a social trait-evaluation interaction. The task and contrast probe perception/understanding of others (other-related feedback), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, task-evoked fMRI activation contrast indexing trial-by-trial feedback processing about self and others (updating of character-trait ratings after partner feedback) in healthy adult participants. The task probes social feedback and bonding-related learning (relevant to affiliation/attachment), and the report lists whole-brain significant activations (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked, voxelwise fMRI analysis of trial-by-trial feedback (self vs other) from healthy adult participants in a social face-to-face feedback task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast and directly measures social-communication (exchange of socially relevant feedback), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain analysis of trial-by-trial feedback discrepancies for self (and other) during a trait-feedback task involving healthy adult participants. The contrast measures self-related feedback processing (Perception and Understanding of Self) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain contrast indexing trial-by-trial feedback discrepancy for self- and other-related feedback, which is a clear social-processing task (updating self/other trait ratings). The sample comprises healthy adult participants and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level task contrast indexing trial-by-trial feedback processing (self vs other) during a face-to-face social interaction in healthy adult participants. The task probes social feedback, conformity and social comparison—processes relevant to affiliation/attachment—and the table reports whole-brain significant activations (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports whole-brain task-evoked activations for trial-by-trial feedback about self and other character traits in a healthy adult sample (German/Chinese participants). The task measures processing of information about another person (trait feedback), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. The entry appears to be a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations to social feedback (self- and other-related feedback discrepancies) in a healthy adult sample. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast and directly measures processing of socially relevant communicated information (feedback), so it fits the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain activation analysis of feedback processing for self (and other) trait ratings in healthy adult participants (no clinical group). The contrast indexes trial-by-trial feedback discrepancy for self (self-related processing), which maps onto Perception and Understanding of Self (self-knowledge/self-monitoring). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast indexing trial-by-trial feedback processing for self and other trait ratings in healthy adult participants. The task directly probes perception/understanding of others (updating ratings about another person), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (20 male volunteers); group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (CV > NV) reporting FWE-corrected activations; task involves viewing campaign videos designed to elicit empathy/social cognition (activation in STS). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and directly measures social processing.

Meets inclusion criteria: group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (CV > NV) in a healthy adult sample (20 males); task involves viewing social/empathy-eliciting campaign videos (reception of socially relevant/non-facial communication), so it indexes social communication processes. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults (CV > NV), the task probes empathy elicited by traffic-awareness campaign videos rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). The contrast does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrast (campaign > neutral videos) in healthy adult participants (20 males). The task probes empathic/social processing (perception/understanding of others) with activations in STS linked to empathy, matching the "perception_others" construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults (CV > NV), the task measures empathy/social perception of others (campaign vs. neutral videos) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (shared emotional viewing > unshared emotional viewing) in healthy adult participants performing a social sharing task. It directly measures social processing (social sharing/affiliation) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (shared vs unshared emotional picture viewing) in healthy adult participants, targeting social sharing with a friend — a measure of affiliation/attachment. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (shared emotional > unshared emotional) indexes social sharing and associated reward-related responses, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or self-monitoring. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy adult group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast compares emotional picture viewing when the participant knows the friend is simultaneously viewing (shared) versus alone — a social presence / sharing manipulation that probes hedonic effects of co-experience, not the perception or inference of others' mental states, traits, actions, or animacy. Although it is a whole‑brain, healthy adult group contrast, it does not target Perception and Understanding of Others as defined (mentalizing/animacy/action perception), so it should be excluded.

The contrast compares viewing emotional pictures together with a friend versus alone, indexing the effect of a social (friend/loved-one) context on neural responses. This is a social communication/social sharing manipulation (akin to kinship/loved-one contrasts) in a healthy adult sample and comes from a whole-brain group-level activation analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within‑subject, group‑level task contrast (Shared_emo > Unshared_emo) in healthy adult participants probing social sharing with a friend. It is a univariate whole‑brain activation contrast indexing affiliation/positive social bonding (sharing with a friend vs alone), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast (shared vs unshared emotional viewing), the contrast indexes social sharing/affiliation and modulation of emotional/reward responses rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. The task measures social/emotional sharing effects, not Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the contrast tests the hedonic effect of socially sharing emotional pictures (shared vs unshared) rather than perception or inference about another person's mental states, traits, actions, or animacy. It reflects social context/reward modulation, not the ‘‘Perception and Understanding of Others’’ construct required for inclusion.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain, within-group task contrast (shared_emo > unshared_emo), the manipulation indexes social sharing/affiliation rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior. There is no receptive/production of facial or non‑facial signals or explicit communication between participants, so it does not meet the annotation's definition of Social Communication.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain univariate contrast (shared_emotion > unshared_emotion) in healthy adult participants measuring social sharing/affiliation (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample examining social sharing of emotions (shared vs unshared) — a clear social-processing task (affiliation). The contrast is a within-subject condition interaction (positive vs negative sharing), not a between-group or ROI/ connectivity analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample; group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast. The task manipulates social sharing with a friend (affiliation/close-relationship context), and the contrast is a within-subject interaction of sharedness × valence rather than a between-group or ROI/connectivity analysis, so it meets the affiliation/attachment criteria.

Although the contrast is a within-group, whole-brain healthy-adult analysis, the task manipulates co-viewing/shared experience rather than an exchange or encoding/production of social communicative signals. The annotation target is "social_communication" (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communication); this study measures social presence/affiliation (sharing experience) without interpersonal communication, so it does not meet the construct criteria.

Although the contrast comes from a healthy adult, whole-brain fMRI study, it indexes the hedonic effect of socially sharing emotional pictures (shared vs unshared positive > shared vs unshared negative) rather than tasks that require perceiving or reasoning about others' mental states, traits, or emotions. The contrast reflects social context/affect regulation, not Perception and Understanding of Others, so it does not meet the "perception_others" construct criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes the effect of social sharing of emotional pictures (valence × sharing interaction) and reflects social/reward processing rather than processes of self‑perception or self‑knowledge. It is not a task/contrast that explicitly measures perception or understanding of the self (e.g., self vs other, self‑trait judgments, social comparison), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast examining social sharing with a friend (shared vs unshared), i.e. an affiliation/attachment task. Contrast captures affiliation-related effects (shared vs alone), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, within-subject univariate whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants probing the effect of social sharing (shared vs unshared) during emotional picture viewing (an affiliation/social processing task). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group (patient vs control) analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes social sharing (viewing pictures together vs alone) but does not involve exchange or processing of socially communicative signals (no face/gesture/verbal communication or reception/production of social signals). The task manipulated co-presence/shared experience rather than social communication per the annotation definition, so it does not meet the 'social_communication' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level univariate contrast (shared > unshared) from a healthy adult sample of friends viewing pictures. The contrast indexes social sharing/affiliation (social processing) and is reported as whole-brain regional activation (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adults (not an ROI or connectivity analysis), the contrast probes social sharing of emotional pictures (valence × sharing interaction) and neural reward responses to shared vs unshared viewing. It does not target processes of self-perception/self-knowledge or agency (i.e., judgments or representations about the self), so it does not meet the "perception_self" task/content requirement.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults probing social sharing (shared vs unshared viewing). It indexes participants' awareness of/co-experience with another person (a social percept/context) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (shared vs unshared viewing), the manipulation indexes social sharing/affiliation and reward responses to viewing with a friend rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge or agency. The contrast does not target Perception and Understanding of the Self, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

Although the study uses a social context (viewing pictures together vs alone) with healthy adults and likely reports whole-brain group contrasts, the contrast (shared_neu > unshared_neu) reflects social sharing/affiliation without any exchange or communicative behavior. The annotation's Social Communication construct requires tasks measuring the exchange of socially relevant information (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communication). Because there was no communication or interaction between participants, this contrast does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (shared_neu > unshared_neu), it indexes the impact of social context / shared experience rather than explicit perception or inference about another person's mental or emotional state. It does not measure understanding or assessment of others’ emotions/traits/abilities, so it does not meet the "perception_others" construct.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain task contrast (deception vs truth) in a healthy adult sample probing strategic social behavior (intention to deceive/mentalizing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast (simple and sophisticated deception vs. truth) examines communicative behavior in a game-theoretic social interaction (deception), uses group-level voxelwise activation coordinates (whole-brain univariate contrast), and the sample appears to be healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast comparing viewing with a friend (shared) versus alone (unshared) in a healthy adult sample. The task probes social sharing between friends (an affiliative manipulation), so the contrast indexes affiliation/attachment rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (deception vs truth) in a healthy adult sample probing strategic social interaction. The contrasts (simple and sophisticated deception vs truth) index representing others' beliefs/intentions (mentalizing) — supported by rTPJ and precuneus activations — and therefore meet the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes intention to deceive in strategic social interaction (lying vs truth; sophisticated deception) — primarily measuring deceptive intent/mentalizing about others rather than explicit processes of self‑perception, self‑knowledge, or agency as defined for the "perception_self" construct. Activation of regions sometimes linked to self-processing (e.g., precuneus) does not by itself make the contrast a measure of Perception/Understanding of Self.

The contrast targets deception/sophisticated deception versus truth in a game-theoretic task, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation focused on attachment). Although it appears to be a whole-brain, healthy adult group analysis, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment processes, so it should be excluded.

The contrast examines deception in strategic interactions (lying vs truth) rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation specifically focused on social bonds). Although it involves social interaction, the task targets deception/theory-of-mind/strategic behavior, not affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the task-domain inclusion criteria.

The contrast (simple deception vs truth) comes from a whole-brain, group-level univariate analysis in a healthy adult sample and probes social/strategic interaction processes (intention to deceive, inferring others' beliefs), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (mentalizing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (simple deception vs. truth) in a healthy adult sample, measuring social processes (deception/strategic interaction, social communication and intent-to-deceive). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (simple deception vs. truth) in healthy adults probing communicative behavior within strategic interactions (exchange/misrepresentation of socially relevant information). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is from a healthy adult, whole-brain contrast (lying vs truth), the task targets deception and intention in strategic social interactions (social cognition/theory-of-mind) rather than explicit processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency as defined for the "perception_self" construct. Therefore it does not meet the construct-specific inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (sophisticated deception vs. truth) in presumably healthy adult participants measuring deception/intention to deceive—processes involving social cognition (rTPJ, precuneus, aFG). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (sophisticated deception vs. truth) in a healthy adult sample, probing strategic communicative behavior (deceptive/truthful message production) — a form of social communication (production of non‑facial communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (sophisticated deception vs truth). The contrast targets the sender's veridical intention to deceive (self-related intention/agency and self-monitoring), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Self construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants (sophisticated deception vs. truth), the task probes strategic deception/intent to deceive rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation/cohesion). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' annotation.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain contrast (sophisticated deception vs truth) reported with voxel coordinates and cluster sizes in a healthy adult sample. The contrast probes participants' representation of others' beliefs/intentions (intent to deceive, i.e., mentalizing/theory-of-mind), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast examines deception (lies vs. truth / sophisticated deception) in strategic interaction, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition focused on bonding). Although the sample and whole-brain group analysis appear acceptable, the task/contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (deception vs truth) in a healthy adult sample probing communicative behavior in strategic interactions (deceptive information exchange). The contrast measures social communication (production of non‑facial communicative content—lying/sophisticated deception), and it is not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (lying/sophisticated-deception vs truth) that probes participants' representation of others' beliefs/intentions (mentalizing). The paradigm targets understanding of others in strategic interactions and yields activations in canonical social-cognition regions (rTPJ, precuneus), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (truth vs. deception/sophisticated deception) in a healthy adult sample probing deception in strategic social interactions. The contrast targets social-cognitive processes (intention to deceive/theory-of-mind/social communication), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis—therefore it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise (whole-brain) task contrast of deception/sophisticated deception vs truth in a healthy adult sample, reporting activation coordinates and probabilities. The task probes social cognition (deception/intentions in strategic interactions), so it meets the social processing inclusion criteria and does not fall under ROI, connectivity, or between-group exclusion criteria.

Although the study used healthy adults and reports whole-brain group contrasts, the contrast indexes deception in strategic interactions (intent to mislead others) and primarily taps social/mentalizing processes (e.g., rTPJ, ToM) rather than explicit self-perception, self-evaluation, or self-knowledge. The task does not measure judgments about the self or self-monitoring per the 'perception_self' construct, so it should be excluded.

The contrast examines lying vs truth-telling in a game-theoretic interactive setting (intentional deception in communication), which is an exchange of socially relevant information and fits the social_communication construct. The sample appears to be healthy adult participants, and the reported Talairach coordinates/posterior probabilities indicate a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast tests deception (truth vs simple/sophisticated deception) in a game-theoretic strategic interaction, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/close-relationship scales). Although the sample appears to be healthy and the analysis is whole-brain, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from a healthy adult sample probing deception/sophisticated deception in strategic interactions — a task that requires reasoning about others' beliefs/intentions (mentalizing). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants probing deception in strategic interactions—a clear social communication / social cognition task (intentions to deceive, understanding others' payoffs). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This analysis examines deception in strategic interactions (lying vs truth, incentive to deceive) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding, attachment styles). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (truth vs. deception), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis. The contrast probes participants' veridical intention to deceive (agency/self-referential decision-making and self-monitoring), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Self (agency/self-knowledge). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (deception vs. truth; parametric modeling of incentive to deceive) in a healthy adult sample investigating communicative behavior in strategic interactions (intention to deceive). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and clearly measures social communication (production of non‑facial communicative behavior), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analysis in healthy adults correlating activation with 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. Imitation/spontaneous imitation is a social-processing construct (social learning/communication), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task contrast in healthy adults probing deception in strategic interactions — a task that requires reasoning about others' beliefs/intentions (mentalizing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and therefore fits the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, within-group correlation in healthy adults, the task and contrast index an urge to imitate meaningless actions (imitation drive), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation_attachment task criterion.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, within-group correlation in healthy adults, the task probes urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (motor imitation) rather than exchange or perception/production of socially communicative signals. It does not measure social communication (no communicative intent, facial/non‑facial signaling, or social interaction contrast), so it fails the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked activations that positively correlate with subjects' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal cognitive/emotional state). The sample is healthy adults and the contrast/index measures a self-evaluative internal state (self-knowledge/awareness), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis—therefore it meets the perception_self criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis in healthy adults linking brain activation to the subjective 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of others' actions. It targets action perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the contrast indexes strategic deception/intention toward others (incentive to deceive, sender–receiver payoffs) and taps social strategic decision-making/mentalizing rather than core self-perception/self-knowledge or agency. Therefore it does not meet the construct definition for Perception and Understanding of Self.

Healthy adult sample, group-level whole-brain voxelwise analysis correlating brain activation with participants' 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. The task probes social behavior (imitation/perception of others' actions), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast — therefore it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a within-group, whole-brain correlation in healthy adults, the task measures an 'urge to imitate' meaningless actions (imitation drive), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the required task/domain inclusion criteria for 'affiliation_attachment.'

The analysis is a PPI (psychophysiological interaction) connectivity analysis. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI); it is therefore not a whole-brain univariate task-evoked group activation map, so it should not be included despite the social/imitation task and healthy sample.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI analysis in healthy adults, the contrast indexes an "urge to imitate" for meaningless bimanual actions rather than measures of social communicative exchange (receptive or productive facial/non‑facial communication). The task probes spontaneous imitation/ motor drive, not social communication per the defined constructs, so it does not meet the Social_Communication inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants; group-level whole-brain voxelwise analysis correlating brain activation with participants' self-rated 'urge to imitate' (an introspective/internal state about the self). This measures perception/awareness of an internal self-state (fits Perception and Understanding of Self) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Healthy adult sample; the reported analysis is a group-level, voxelwise correlation between brain activation and subjective 'urge to imitate' (a task-evoked, within-group univariate effect) during observation/imitation of others' actions, which maps onto Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, between-group, or connectivity (PPI) result.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis (seed-based), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. Additionally, the task measures urge to imitate rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm, so it does not meet the task/contrast inclusion requirements.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) effective/seed-based connectivity analysis (reported in the table caption), which falls under the exclusion criteria. This is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis (seed-based/effective connectivity), which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. The inclusion rules require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise map; a PPI does not meet that requirement.

The reported analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis. The analysis measures the 'urge to imitate' for meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation) rather than affiliation or attachment-related processes (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate analysis in healthy adults, the task probes an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (an imitative/motor drive) rather than the exchange or reception/production of socially meaningful communicative signals. This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain correlation of task-evoked activation in healthy adult participants (Urge to imitate during observation/imitation), not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task involves observing and imitating others' actions (a social process related to perception/understanding of others and social imitation), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an introspective, current internal state). That measure indexes self-awareness/self-monitoring (self-knowledge/agency), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Self construct and meets the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria (not ROI or connectivity).

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults relating brain activity during observation of others' actions to ratings of 'urge to imitate.' The task probes action perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast—so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports group-level voxelwise correlations with an 'urge to imitate' (likely whole-brain), the task probes spontaneous imitation drive of meaningless actions rather than affiliation or attachment processes (no kinship/close-relationship/cooperation/attachment manipulation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment category.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain correlation between task-evoked activation and participants' 'urge to imitate' in healthy adults during an imitation task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Although the actions were meaningless, the task probes spontaneous imitation — a social learning/interaction-related process — so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain task-evoked correlations, the task measures spontaneous motor imitation of meaningless bimanual actions (urge to imitate) rather than exchange or processing of socially relevant communicative signals. This does not fit the Social Communication construct (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative acts), so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with participants' self-reported internal state ('urge to imitate'). The measure indexes an introspective/current internal state (self-monitoring/self-knowledge) rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the 'perception and understanding of self' inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants performing an observation/imitation task; the reported analysis is a group-level voxelwise correlation (brain activations correlated with 'urge to imitate'), not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The task probes spontaneous imitation—an interpersonal/social behavior (perception of others' actions and drive to imitate)—so it meets the social-processing inclusion criteria.

The analysis probes participants' 'urge to imitate' meaningless bimanual actions (spontaneous imitation), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although the sample appears to be healthy adults and the result is a whole‑brain correlation, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with the urge to imitate during observation/imitation of others' actions. The task probes action perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI or resting-state/seed connectivity analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the task indexes an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (an imitation/motor drive), not the reception or production of socially communicative signals. This is a group-level, voxelwise task activation analysis in healthy adults relating brain activity to the reported 'urge to imitate' while observing/imitating others' actions. Although the analysis appears to be a whole-brain, group-level correlation in healthy adults, the task and contrast measure an 'urge to imitate' meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation). This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' — an introspective judgment about an internal state. Healthy adult participants; the reported analysis is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain correlation of task-evoked activation with 'urge to imitate' (within the imitation condition), not an ROI or connectivity-only analysis. The task probes spontaneous imitation, a social behavior relevant to social processing (social learning/communication), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although the sample and analysis appear to be whole-brain, the task indexes an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (motor imitation/learning), not the exchange or recognition of socially relevant communicative signals. Healthy adult sample; the reported analysis is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain correlation (activation correlated with 'urge to imitate') during an imitation/observation task (action perception). This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis in healthy adults examining brain activity correlated with 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of actions. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adult participants correlating brain activation with subjects' self-rated 'urge to imitate' — an introspective, current internal state / self-monitoring measure. It is not an ROI, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it fits the perception_self inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, task‑evoked correlation in healthy adults, the task measures an 'urge to imitate' meaningless bimanual actions rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task analysis in healthy adults reporting brain activations (positive correlations with subjective 'urge to imitate') during observation/imitation of others' actions. The task involves action perception (observing others' bimanual actions), meeting the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (Action Perception) criterion. Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level activation correlated with an urge-to-imitate in healthy adults, the task used meaningless bimanual actions and probes an imitation drive / motor propensity rather than an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals. This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise analysis in healthy adults correlating BOLD with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an introspective/internal state). This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis in healthy adults showing brain activation correlated with participants' reported 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. The task probes spontaneous imitation (a social/interactive drive related to perception/response to others), and the reported result is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group contrast—so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This analysis probes the neural correlates of an 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of meaningless actions — a motor/spontaneous imitation task — not a measure of affiliation or attachment (social bonding, close relationships, or kinship). Although it is a whole-brain group-level effect in healthy adults, it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise correlation in healthy adults (so it meets the sample and analysis-type criteria), the task probes urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions rather than exchange or perception/production of socially communicative signals. Healthy adult sample and the reported analysis is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise correlation of task-evoked activation with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal self-state). This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults (brain activations parametrically correlated with "urge to imitate" during observation/ imitation of others’ actions). This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (ToM > R) probing Theory of Mind, which is a canonical social-processing construct (perception/understanding of others). Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes Theory-of-Mind (mentalizing) processing (ToM > R) rather than an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment annotation.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (ToM > R) from a Theory-of-Mind task, which directly maps onto the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others. The table caption indicates whole-brain voxelwise results (not ROI or connectivity) and the study concerns healthy adult participants, so it meets the inclusion criteria and none of the exclusions apply.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (ToM > R) indexes theory-of-mind/mentalizing about others rather than processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. It therefore does not meet the domain requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast indexes Theory-of-Mind (mentalizing) rather than an exchange/production or reception of social communication per the annotation (facial/non‑facial communication) subconstructs. Therefore it does not meet the specified "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

The contrast (ToM > R) targets social processing in (presumably) healthy adults, but this specific analysis is a VOI/ROI-based Bayesian comparison extracting mean BOLD within 15 mm spheres (mPFC and right pSTG). This is an ROI/VOI Bayesian comparison of mPFC vs right pSTG responses for a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) contrast. The reported analysis is a VOI/ROI Bayesian comparison (mean and SD of BOLD within specified 15 mm volumes) rather than a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrast. ROI/VOI analyses are listed in the exclusion criteria, so it does not meet the whole-brain inclusion requirement for the social_communication annotation.

This is an ROI/VOI Bayesian comparison (mean BOLD within 15 mm VOIs) of mPFC vs right pSTG during a Theory-of-Mind (ToM) contrast. Therefore it fails the whole-brain and task-domain/inclusion criteria (and ROI analyses are explicitly excluded).

Although the contrast (ToM > R) targets Theory-of-Mind / understanding others (fits the perception_others construct), this specific analysis is a VOI/ROI-based Bayesian comparison (mean BOLD in mPFC vs r-pSTG within 15 mm spheres) rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task map. The inclusion criteria require univariate whole-brain, group-level voxelwise evidence, and ROI analyses are excluded.

The contrast is Words > Faces from a language/communication study and does not probe affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group analysis on healthy participants, the task/contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it fails the task-specific inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from a healthy adult sample, the contrast 'Words > Faces' indexes greater activation for word stimuli relative to face stimuli (language/visual-category processing) rather than a social-communicative process. Although this is a whole-brain random-effects contrast on healthy adults, the contrast (Words > Faces) indexes language vs face perception/processing related to communicative actions, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrast (Request > Naming) from a fMRI task that probes communicative/social actions (understanding Requests vs Naming). Although this is a whole‑brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Words > Faces) indexes language/word processing relative to face stimuli rather than Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., animacy, action perception, or mental state understanding). Therefore it does not meet the task/contrast requirement for the perception_others construct.

The contrast is Words > Faces — a stimulus-category contrast — and does not specifically index social-communication processes (e.g., speech-act contexts like Request vs Name or reception/production of communicative signals). Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts speech-act types (Request vs Naming) and probes communicative/action understanding—not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects contrast (Request > Naming) in healthy adults probing speech acts/communicative intentions (production of non-facial social communication). The contrast (Request > Naming) probes understanding of communicative actions / speech acts (social/interactional processing), not self-related cognition (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). The contrast is a whole-brain random-effects group analysis in healthy adults (Request > Naming) probing understanding of communicative actions/intentions (social interactive knowledge). The contrast isolates understanding of Requests versus Naming in healthy adult participants and comes from a whole-brain random-effects group contrast (task-evoked fMRI). The contrast (Request > Naming) probes different speech-act/communicative actions (requesting vs naming) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although the analysis is likely a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, it does not target affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares understanding of Requests versus Naming (speech acts), which directly probes communicative actions/social communication (production/reception of non-facial communication). The contrast (Request > Naming) probes comprehension of speech acts/communicative actions (social/interactional processes), not self-related processing (agency or self-knowledge). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The contrast Request > Naming probes understanding of communicative actions (interpreting others' speech acts/intentions), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others. The report describes a whole-brain random-effects group contrast in healthy adults (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the sample and whole-brain inclusion criteria. Although the study used healthy adults and a whole-brain contrast (Naming > Request), the task compares types of communicative speech acts (naming vs requesting) and does not probe affiliation or attachment (close relationships, bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, the contrast (Naming > Request) isolates activation for naming relative to a communicative/request condition. The social aspect of the task is indexed by Request > Naming, not Naming > Request, so this particular contrast does not meet the criterion of measuring social processing.

The contrast (Naming > Request) probes different speech acts (communicative actions) in healthy adults and the table reports a whole-brain random-effects analysis (voxelwise group contrast). This is a within-group task-evoked comparison of social communication (production/interpretation of non-facial communicative acts), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Naming > Request) probes language/communicative action processing (speech act comprehension), not self-related cognition (agency or self-knowledge). Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure perception or understanding of the self, so it does not meet the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain main effect contrast (Bodies > Names) from a task probing person perception/person knowledge in healthy adults. The contrast (Bodies > Names) indexes person perception / social agent processing rather than affiliation or attachment. Although the study used communicative contexts and the experiment is whole-brain in healthy adults, the specific contrast is Naming > Request. Although this is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (Bodies > Names), it indexes person perception of others (bodies versus names) rather than processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Bodies > Names) indexes person perception (visual/identity processing) rather than social communication or exchange of socially relevant information. This is a group-level univariate contrast (Main effect Social Agent: Bodies > Names) from a healthy adult fMRI study probing perception of other people (bodies vs names). This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (Main effect Social Knowledge: Traits > Neutral) from a task that elicits trait inferences about others, i.e. social processing. Although this is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (Main effect Social Knowledge: Traits > Neutral), the task probes trait-based social knowledge/mentalising rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, parental/peer bonding, loved-one vs stranger). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults (Traits > Neutral), it reflects person knowledge about other people (trait-implying statements paired with bodies/names) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-related judgement. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (Traits > Neutral) from a healthy adult fMRI study probing trait-based person knowledge/mentalising. Although this is a healthy-group, whole-brain univariate main effect (Traits > Neutral), the contrast indexes person-knowledge / trait inference rather than social communication (exchange or reception/production of communicative signals). It does not measure a social-communication task/contrast as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level univariate voxelwise interaction contrast testing person perception/knowledge (Bodies vs Names × Traits vs Neutral) in a healthy adult sample. This contrast probes person perception and person-knowledge for other agents (bodies vs names paired with trait vs neutral statements), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although this is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast, the task and contrast probe person perception and trait knowledge (bodies vs names; trait-implying vs neutral statements), not affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for an affiliation/attachment task.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adults that tests person perception/person-knowledge (traits paired with bodies vs names). It is a within-subject interaction about perception and understanding of others, not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain within-subject contrast (interaction of agent: bodies vs names × knowledge: trait vs neutral) from a healthy adult sample, not an ROI or connectivity analysis. The contrast indexes processing of socially relevant person information (trait-implying statements and person perception/characterization), which falls under social communication (receptive/characterization aspects). This is a seed-based functional connectivity analysis (seed: right fusiform gyrus / PPI-style coupling) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast, and the task probes person perception/person-knowledge (trait inference) rather than affiliation/attachment. The analysis is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: right fusiform gyrus) rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task activation map. Per the criteria, seed/PPI connectivity analyses are excluded even though the task is social and the sample is healthy adults.

This analysis is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: right fusiform gyrus), not a group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrast; seed/PPI-type connectivity analyses are excluded. Additionally, the study addresses person perception/person knowledge about others rather than Perception/Understanding of the self.

The analysis is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: right fusiform gyrus). The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map; seed-based/effective connectivity (e.g., PPI) is explicitly excluded.

The analysis is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: right fusiform gyrus / PPI-style functional coupling), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrast. Seed-based connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria; therefore it should not be included.

The analysis is labelled as a 'Seed region: left temporal pole', indicating a seed-based functional connectivity analysis (e.g., PPI), which is explicitly excluded. This is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: left temporal pole), not a group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked map, and seed/PPI connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded. The analysis is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: left temporal pole). Even though the study concerns social perception, the inclusion criteria require group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts. This analysis is not appropriate for the "perception_self" label. In addition, the task and contrasts reported relate to perceiving/inferring traits of other people (person perception/knowledge), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge required for the "perception_self" construct.

The entry is a seed-based connectivity analysis (seed: left temporal pole) rather than a group-level univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrast measuring social communication. The study focuses on person perception/knowledge and reports functional coupling (connectivity/PPI-like) results, which are explicitly excluded by the criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast ((toss – button press) high-frequency) in a sample of healthy adult participants performing a social interaction (ball-toss) task that probes social reward/affiliation. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adults (n=38) contrasting social toss events against a control (button press) during a ball‑toss game manipulating social inclusion (high-frequency tosses). The task measures social interaction/social reward (affiliation/attachment) and the analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise comparison (toss – button press) in a sample of healthy adults (N=38). The task is a social ball‑toss interaction (social reward/interaction manipulation), which fits the Social Communication domain (reception of non‑facial social interaction/cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting‑state, or between‑group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (38 participants) comparing a social toss condition to a button-press baseline in a virtual ball-toss game. This task probes social interaction/perception of others (cooperation/social inclusion), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate contrast in a healthy adult sample (n=38) (toss – button press, high-frequency). The task probes social interaction frequency that the authors interpret as affecting positive self-image/ self-related processing (precuneus) and reward tied to interaction preference, so it fits the "Perception and Understanding of Self" construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (healthy male volunteers) comparing aggressive responses to a provoking vs non-provoking opponent. The task involves social interaction/retaliation (social processing), and the analysis is univariate whole-brain (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast indexes retaliation/aggressive responses to provocation (anger/aggression), not affiliation or attachment processes. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not measure affiliation/attachment, so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion.

Healthy adult whole-brain voxelwise group contrast examining responses to a provoking vs non‑provoking opponent (social interaction/retaliation). This task probes perception/assessment of others' actions (provocation) and fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct; it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain task contrast in a sample of healthy adult volunteers, comparing responses to provoking vs non‑provoking opponents in an interpersonal aggression paradigm. The task probes social interaction/retaliation processes (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (15 healthy males) comparing responses to a provoking vs non-provoking opponent — a social interaction/competition paradigm measuring retaliatory behavior. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and fits the Social Communication domain (competition/interaction).
