Although it appears to be a group-level whole-brain contrast, the task and contrast do not evaluate affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) analysis linking brain activity during reading/abstract trials to population-level article virality. The task measures social-relevant processes (valuation of sharing and expected social consequences, i.e., social communication/approval), participants are healthy adults, and the map is a univariate whole-brain contrast rather than an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison — so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports brain activity related to population-level virality/valuation of news articles during reading/abstract trials, not measures of perception or understanding of the self (no self-related judgments, self vs other contrasts, or kinship/social-comparison tasks). Thus it does not meet the task/content requirements for the "perception_self" construct.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group-level map in healthy adults, it indexes neural responses to article virality during reading rather than a task or contrast that probes social communication (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative behavior). The comparison does not involve an explicit social-communication condition (e.g., interaction, sharing vs not sharing, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The reported contrast concerns brain clusters tracking population-level virality of news articles (valuation/virality during reading), not a task measuring perception or understanding of other people (mentalizing, animacy/action perception, social comparison, etc.). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group map in healthy adults, the cognitive domain does not match the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise contrast (Mentalising > Factual memory) from an fMRI experiment on healthy adult participants; mentalising/theory-of-mind is a social-processing task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a mentalising (theory-of-mind) > factual memory task. Although it is a whole-brain, group-level healthy adult contrast, it does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Mentalising > Factual memory) from an fMRI experiment on healthy adult participants that directly probes understanding others' mental states (mentalising/theory of mind). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast Mentalising > Factual memory targets theory-of-mind/mentalising (understanding others' intentions) rather than Perception and Understanding of the Self. Therefore it does not meet the domain requirement for the "perception_self" annotation.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it indexes mentalising/theory-of-mind (inferring others' mental states) rather than measures of social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchanges). The annotation target is specifically about communicative behavior/exchange, so a ToM > factual memory contrast does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This contrast reflects mentalising (theory-of-mind) versus factual memory processing, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although it is a whole‑brain, healthy adult group task contrast, it does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (mentalising parametric > factual memory parametric) from an fMRI experiment on healthy adult participants, indexing theory-of-mind/mentalising (a social processing construct). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast tests mentalising (theory-of-mind) versus factual memory, which targets understanding others' mental states rather than self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast probes mentalising/theory-of-mind (inference about others' mental states) versus factual memory. The annotation target is specifically Social Communication (exchange of socially relevant information, receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication). Mentalising per se is social cognition but not an assessment of social communication as defined here, so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Mentalising parametric > Factual memory parametric) from an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants, targeting theory-of-mind/mentalising (Understanding Mental States). It is task-evoked, not ROI- or connectivity-based, and thus meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis from healthy adult participants examining higher-order intentionality/mentalising (theory-of-mind) vs factual memory. The task probes social cognition (understanding others), and the table reports whole-brain corrected activations — it therefore meets the sample, whole-brain, and social-processing inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The analysis reports common activations for higher-order mentalising (theory-of-mind) versus factual memory; the task measures intentionality/mentalising, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Although it is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, it does not meet the task/content requirement for affiliation_attachment.

Although the study uses healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked results, the contrast reflects higher-order intentionality / theory-of-mind (mentalising) versus factual memory and common areas across those conditions. This targets understanding others' mental states (social cognition) rather than perception/understanding of the self (self-awareness, self-knowledge or agency), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI analysis of mentalising (theory-of-mind) in a healthy adult sample from Experiment 2, reporting whole-brain corrected activations for a social-cognitive (mentalising/intentionality) task. It therefore meets the sample, whole-brain, and social-processing inclusion criteria and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Although this is a healthy adult, group-level whole-brain contrast, the task probes higher-order intentionality / mentalising (theory-of-mind) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behaviour per the "social_communication" definition. The contrast does not clearly measure reception/production of facial or non‑facial communication (e.g., cooperation, kinship scenarios, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast from an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (n=17) reporting regions engaged by higher-order intentionality/mentalising tasks (understanding others' mental states). The table caption reports whole-brain correction (P<0.001, k>38), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This analysis probes mentalising/higher-order theory-of-mind (reading stories and intentionality), not affiliation or attachment. Although it appears to be a whole‑brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not measure affiliation/close relationships/attachment, so it fails the content inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast from healthy adult participants probing mentalising/theory-of-mind (understanding others' mental states). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.

This analysis probes mentalising/higher-order intentionality (theory-of-mind about others) rather than perception or understanding of the self. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adults, it does not meet the construct requirement (Perception and Understanding of Self) and therefore should be excluded.

This is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast from an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=17) examining mentalising (theory-of-mind) load via story-based tasks. Mentalising/story comprehension counts as reception of non-facial social communication (processing socially relevant information), and the reported contrast is neither an ROI nor connectivity or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from healthy adults, the contrast is a 'factual memory parametric' effect (a non-social memory/control condition) rather than a measure of social cognition/theory-of-mind. It therefore does not meet the requirement that the analysis measure Social Processing.

The contrast is a 'Factual memory parametric' analysis (a control/non-social memory condition) from a theory-of-mind study, not a task or contrast measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group map on healthy adults, it does not meet the content requirement of assessing affiliation/attachment.

This contrast is a parametric modulation of a factual memory condition (non-social) rather than a social-communication task/contrast. Although the study includes mentalising contrasts elsewhere, this specific analysis measures factual memory and therefore does not meet the content requirement for Social Communication. (It does appear to be a whole-brain, healthy adult group map, but fails the task/content inclusion criterion.)

This contrast investigates factual memory (parametric modulation) from a story-reading task, not processes of self-perception/self-knowledge or judgments about the self. Although it is a whole-brain group univariate result in healthy adults, it does not meet the task/content requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The analysis is a 'Factual memory parametric' contrast (non-social factual memory), not a measure of perceiving or understanding others' mental states. Although the study includes mentalising tasks, this specific contrast does not target social/mental-state processing, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a movie-watching task in healthy adults that probes social cognition (kinship effects on moral/social evaluation). It is not an ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, and thus meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a movie-watching task manipulating kinship. Participants are healthy adults and the contrast probes kinship/affiliation (genetic vs non-genetic sister), which fits the affiliation/attachment domain. The analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, effective-connectivity, or resting-state study, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a movie-watching task in healthy adults probing kinship-related social scenarios. The contrast directly tests a social-communication manipulation (kinship vs non-kin), is not an ROI or seed/connectivity analysis, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) during a movie-based social/kinship moral task in healthy adults assessing responses to others (kin vs non-kin). The contrast indexes differential neural responses to perceived kinship (a Perception and Understanding of Others manipulation). It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a movie-watching task in healthy adult participants examining responses to kinship-related scenarios. That matches the inclusion examples (kinship-related social scenarios) and is not an ROI, seed-based/EC/ resting-state, or between-group analysis. Although the metric is inter-subject correlation rather than a standard GLM contrast, the table reports voxelwise t-values at the group level, so it is acceptable for the perception_self annotation.

This is a within-subject, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (non-genetic > genetic) derived from a movie-watching task manipulating perceived kinship — a social processing paradigm. Participants are healthy adults, the result is a group-level voxelwise map (clusters/peak t-values) rather than an ROI or seed-based connectivity analysis, and the contrast directly targets social cognition (moral/kinship processing). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the task (kinship in a moral dilemma) and sample (healthy adults) match the affiliation/attachment domain, this analysis is an inter-subject correlation (synchrony) comparison (non-genetic > genetic) rather than a standard group-level, univariate voxelwise task-evoked GLM contrast. The inclusion criteria require a univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map; ISC/synchrony-type analyses are connectivity-like and do not meet that requirement.

This is a within-group, voxelwise contrast from a movie-watching task in healthy adult participants comparing kinship conditions (non-genetic > genetic). The task is a kinship-related social scenario (fits Social Communication), the table reports whole-brain cluster peaks/t-values (not an ROI), and the contrast is task-evoked rather than resting-state or seed/connectivity. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrast (non-genetic > genetic) from a movie-based kinship manipulation in healthy adult participants. The task involves kinship-related social scenarios (genetic vs. adopted sister), which matches the 'Kinship-related social scenarios' example under Perception and Understanding of Self. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (comparing inter-subject correlation between conditions) from healthy adult subjects viewing a moral/kinship movie — a clearly social-processing task (moral/emotional conflict, mentalizing). It is not an ROI, seed-based/effective-connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical comparison, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (comparison of inter-subject correlation maps) in healthy adult subjects viewing kinship-related moral scenarios (genetic vs adopted sisters). The task directly probes kinship/affiliation, it is not an ROI or seed/connectivity or between-group patient contrast, and the reported clusters reflect whole-brain results, so it meets the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level, voxelwise contrast from a movie-watching task manipulating perceived kinship (non-genetic > genetic) in healthy adult participants. The contrast probes perception/understanding of others (kinship-related social scenarios) and the table reports whole-brain cluster-level t values (not an ROI or seed/connectivity analysis), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (clusters and t-values reported) comparing brain responses when subjects viewed a kinship-related moral dilemma (genetic vs adopted sisters). The sample is healthy adults, the task measures a social-communication construct (kinship-related social scenarios), and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based/effective connectivity, or between-group clinical comparison. Although the metric is inter-subject correlation, it is reported as a voxelwise group contrast and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the task involves kinship (relevant to Perception and Understanding of Self), the reported analysis is an inter-subject correlation (synchrony) comparison between viewing conditions rather than a group-level univariate, voxelwise task-evoked contrast. This ISC-style connectivity/synchrony analysis does not meet the requirement for a whole-brain univariate task activation map, so it should be excluded.

FT>FA is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast from an fMRI study where healthy adult participants judged whether biological motion stimuli faced toward vs away — a social-perception task probing social involvement/intent. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task (judging biological motion/whether point‑light or walker stimuli face toward vs away) measures stimulus direction/social perception, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close‑relationship, cooperation comparisons). The contrast FT>FA (facing toward > facing away) does not index affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked, whole-brain voxelwise contrast comparing brain responses when subjects believed sisters were genetic vs adopted (a kinship-related social scenario). The sample appears to be healthy adults and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group comparison. Although the metric is inter-subject correlation, it yields group-level whole-brain statistical maps indexing perception/understanding of others (kinship), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

FT > FA is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults and not an ROI/ connectivity/ between-group analysis. The task required judging whether point-light or human-like walkers were facing toward vs away, which indexes perception of social intent/body-orientation (reception of non‑facial social communication). Therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

FT > FA is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing stimuli facing toward vs away (biological motion/social direction) during an observer judgment task. This measures perception/action/animacy of others, is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, and is from a healthy adult sample — therefore it meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

Although FT>FA is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts stimuli facing toward versus away from the observer (perception of others' orientation/social involvement). This indexes perception of stimulus-directedness rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or explicit self-related judgment required by the 'perception_self' construct, so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes perception of biological motion/direction (facing toward vs away) and 'potential for social involvement' rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

FA>FT is a within-group, task-evoked contrast from a study where healthy adults judged facing direction of biological motion/human-like walkers (a social perception task). This is a univariate task contrast indexing perception/understanding of others (social processing), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-subject, group-level task contrast (HL > PLD) from an fMRI experiment in healthy adults performing a social perception task (judging facing direction of human-like walkers vs point-light displays). It is a univariate whole-brain task-evoked comparison indexing perception/understanding of others (social processing), and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

FA > FT is a group-level task contrast (facing-away vs facing-toward) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (PLDs/HL), a form of Perception/Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception). It is a whole-brain univariate task contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The FA>FT contrast is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate comparison in healthy adults probing perception of body orientation (facing toward vs away), i.e. nonverbal social cues that modulate potential for social involvement. This fits the 'Reception of Non‑Facial Communication' subconstruct and meets inclusion (not ROI/seed/between-group) criteria.

The HL > PLD contrast contrasts types of observed agents (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) during judgments about stimulus direction/social involvement — i.e., perception of others/biological motion and social intention. It does not target self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge), so it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.

The contrast (HL > PLD) tests processing of biological motion and potential for social involvement (mirror/mentalizing systems) — not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, attachment style, loved-one vs stranger). Although likely a healthy-group whole-brain contrast, the task does not target affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

Although the sample and likely the statistical map meet the ‘healthy adult, whole-brain, group-level’ requirements, the HL > PLD contrast indexes stimulus type/biological motion (human-like walker vs point‑light display) during a direction judgement task rather than a task that explicitly measures social communication (exchange of social information, communicative intent, gaze/face-based reception or production). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's requirement that the analysis measure Social Communication.

The FA>FT contrast indexes perception of others' stimulus direction (facing away vs toward) and social involvement of observed agents, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although performed in healthy adults with a whole-brain contrast, the task probes social perception of others rather than Perception and Understanding of the Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL > PLD) from healthy adult participants probing perception of biological motion/social intent (animacy/action perception). It is a whole-brain univariate contrast related to Perception and Understanding of Others and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast (PLD > HL) reflects differences in processing types of biological motion/social stimuli (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) and stimulus direction, i.e., perception of others' actions/social cues — not judgments or awareness about the self (agency or self-knowledge). Although the study likely used healthy adults and a whole-brain task contrast, the cognitive construct does not match the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (PLD > HL) from a healthy adult sample probing perception/interpretation of human motion (judging facing direction), which taps social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (PLD > HL) in healthy adults from a task where participants judged facing direction — a form of reception of non-facial social communication (biological/body motion conveying social orientation/intent). The contrast indexes processing within a social-perception task (inferring social meaning from body motion), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy group-level, whole-brain task contrast (PLD > HL), the task involves judging biological motion/direction (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) and probes perception of social motion/potential for involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

This is a within-group, univariate contrast (PLD > HL) from a task probing perception of biological/social motion (animacy/action perception) in healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The contrast probes detection of biological motion and stimulus direction (facing toward/away) and engagement of mirror/mentalizing systems, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although likely a healthy adult, whole-brain task contrast, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level task fMRI contrast (STIMULUS × DIRECTION) from healthy adults that probes perception/interpretation of others (point-light and human-like walkers facing toward/away), i.e. social processing. There is no indication it is an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level fMRI contrast (STIMULUS*DIRECTION) in healthy adults assessing whether PLDs/HL walkers face toward or away from the observer — a task probing perception of body-orientation/social intent (reception of non-facial social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This is a group-level task contrast (STIMULUS*DIRECTION) probing perception of biological motion (point-light displays and human-like walkers) — i.e., action/animacy perception relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others. It is not a between-group, ROI, or connectivity analysis and was performed in healthy adults, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a group-level fMRI contrast on healthy adults, the task probes perception of others' biological motion and whether stimuli face toward/away (social involvement). It does not measure self-related processes (self-awareness, agency, self-knowledge) required for the "perception_self" construct, so it should be excluded.

The analysis stems from a task in which healthy adult participants judged social orientation of point-light displays and human-like walkers (a clear social-perception task), and the reported results reflect task-evoked fMRI contrasts implicating mirror and mentalizing systems. Nothing in the provided description indicates an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and the table caption describes whole-brain fMRI analyses. Therefore it meets the sample, whole-brain univariate, and social-processing inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis investigates coding of stimulus direction (facing toward/away) and stimulus type (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) to probe mirror and mentalizing system engagement. Although it concerns social perception/social involvement, it does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, close relationship scales, cooperation/competition). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" label.

The analysis is a group-level task fMRI contrast in healthy adults probing perception of social intent from biological motion (PLDs/face-toward vs away), which constitutes reception of non-facial social communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast reflects perception of others' motion/direction (social involvement of stimuli) rather than judgments about the participant's own traits, states, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it uses an egocentric reference (facing toward vs away), it does not probe self-awareness or self-related processing as defined by the "perception_self" construct.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast probing perception/understanding of others (biological motion, social intentions: PLD vs human-like walkers; facing toward/away). It reports group-level activations in mirror/mentalizing systems in healthy participants and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast comparing PLD versus HL stimuli in healthy adult participants performing a social judgment task (facing toward/away). The contrast indexes social perception/processing (biological motion and social involvement), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This contrast indexes perception of biological motion/direction (PLD vs human-like walkers) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (FT_PLD > HL) from a study in healthy adults comparing types of biological-motion/social stimuli (point-light displays vs human-like walkers). This is a group-level task fMRI contrast (FT_PLD > HL) from a study where healthy adult participants judged whether point-light displays or human-like walkers were facing toward/away — a task probing reception of socially relevant, non-facial communicative cues (body orientation/potential for social involvement). It is not an ROI or connectivity analysis and therefore meets the whole-brain, healthy-sample, social-communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (FT_PLD > HL) indexes perception of stimulus direction/social involvement of others (point-light vs human-like walkers facing the observer). This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (HL > PLD) from a healthy adult sample performing a social perception task (judging facing direction/ social involvement from biological motion). It is a univariate group-level comparison relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of others), and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the study used healthy adults and a whole-brain task contrast, the task (judging biological motion / whether walkers face toward/away) and the contrast (HL vs PLD) probe social perception/mentalizing and potential for social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast comparing human-like walkers (HL) to point-light displays (PLD) during a social perception task (judging facing direction). The contrast (FT_HL > PLD) contrasts stimulus types (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) during a task judging whether stimuli face the observer. Although the task involves judging others' orientation relative to the observer, it does not probe self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency (i.e., judgments about one's own internal states/traits). Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion definition.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults comparing human-like walkers (HL) to point-light displays (PLD) during a task that evaluates stimulus direction/possible social involvement. The task probes reception of non-facial communicative cues (body/biological motion indicating facing/approach), fitting the Social Communication construct (reception of non-facial communication). It does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group contrast).

This is a group-level task contrast (FA_PLD > HL) from a task requiring social-perceptual judgments (point-light displays vs human-like walkers; assessing social intentions/direction), reported in a whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis in healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, and therefore fits the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The contrast (PLD > HL) comes from a task judging stimulus direction of biological motion (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) and probes perception of motion/social intention, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding, parental/peer attachment). Although the sample is likely healthy and the result appears to be a group-level fMRI contrast, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs required by the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult, within-group whole-brain univariate contrast (FA_PLD > HL) assessing perception of body/point-light motion and inferred social intent (facing toward/away). This probes reception of non-facial social communication (body orientation/gaze-like cues), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adults comparing point-light displays (biological motion) to human-like walkers during a direction/facing judgement. It targets perception of others (action/animacy perception) and appears to be a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, task-evoked contrast comparing human-like walkers (HL) vs point-light displays (PLD) during a social judgement task (facing toward/away), performed in healthy adults and reported as whole-brain fMRI results. It measures social-perceptual processing (inference of social meaning/potential for social involvement) and does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (FA_PLD > HL) reflects stimulus-type/direction effects in biological-motion perception (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) rather than measures of self-related processing (self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge). The FA_HL > PLD contrast compares stimulus types (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) in a direction-discrimination task about biological motion. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (HL > PLD) from a task where healthy adults judged facing direction / social involvement of walkers — i.e., perception of socially relevant, non‑facial communication (body/biological motion conveying social intentions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The contrast (HL vs PLD for facing direction) reflects perception of others' biological motion / social involvement (who is facing the observer) rather than judgments about the self (self-knowledge, agency, self-monitoring). Although the task references the observer’s viewpoint, it does not probe self-related traits, states, agency, or self-understanding as required by the 'perception_self' construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level task contrast (PLD facing toward > facing away) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological motion/social orientation. This is a within-group, univariate contrast (HL vs PLD) from a task probing perception of biological motion/social involvement in healthy adult participants. This contrast (PLD_FT > FA) contrasts point‑light displays facing toward vs away and indexes direction/social‑involvement/perception of biological motion, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). The contrast (PLD facing towards > facing away) indexes perception of others' biological motion / stimulus direction and social involvement, not judgments or awareness about the self (agency or self-knowledge). This contrast (PLD_FA > FT) comes from a task in which healthy adult participants judged social directionality of point-light displays (socially relevant biological motion), is a within-group task-evoked univariate contrast (whole-brain group analysis as reported in the fMRI results), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task (judging whether point-light displays/human-like walkers face toward or away from the observer) probes biological motion and stimulus direction/social involvement potential, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (PLD facing away > facing towards) from healthy adults that indexes perception of social orientation/intent from point-light displays. Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the PLD_FA > FT contrast indexes perception of others' orientation (facing-away vs facing-toward) and social involvement/biological-motion processing. This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (human-like walkers facing toward > facing away) from a study on healthy adults probing perception of others/social involvement. This is a within-group task contrast (point-light displays facing away > facing toward) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of others (animacy/action perception). Although the study uses healthy adults and likely reports a group-level whole-brain contrast (HL facing-toward > facing-away), the task contrasts perceptual coding of stimulus direction (potential for social involvement) rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., relationships, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (human-like walkers facing toward vs away). The task assesses perception/inference of socially relevant body-direction/intent (reception of non-facial communication), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked voxelwise contrast (human-like walkers facing away vs facing toward) in healthy adults, probing perception/interpretation of others (social involvement). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a healthy group, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast (HL facing toward > facing away), the contrast indexes perception of another agent's orientation/social involvement (social perception/mentalizing) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or agency. It therefore does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct and should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (human-like walkers facing toward vs away) in a healthy adult sample probing perception of others (biological motion / social orientation), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

The contrast (HL_FA > FT) indexes perception of human-like walkers facing away versus toward (direction/social involvement), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (HL facing away vs facing toward) from a task that probes perception of social orientation/intent (non‑facial communicative cues/body direction). This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants performing a social interaction task (joint/partnered action). HL_FA > FT is a within-group contrast comparing human-like walkers facing away vs facing toward (animacy/social direction). Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (partnered > non‑partnered), the task probes joint motor coordination/role-taking in improvised dance rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationship, attachment style, loved one vs stranger). HL_FA > FT is a group whole-brain contrast comparing human-like walkers facing toward/away the observer (stimulus direction/social involvement). Although it probes perceived social directedness, it does not measure judgments about the self, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the "Perception and Understanding of Self" inclusion requirement.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adults from a joint-action task involving cooperative physical interaction. The task measures social interaction/communication (non‑facial, haptic/movement-based exchange), fitting the Social Communication construct (e.g., cooperation/non‑facial communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants performing a joint-action (leader/follower/mutual) social interaction task. This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (trained dancers) comparing partnered (social interaction) versus non-partnered conditions. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the sample and analysis are whole-brain and from healthy adults, the contrast (partnered > non‑partnered: Leading+Following+Mutual vs Solo+Alone) indexes presence of social/interactive coupling rather than explicit processes of self‑perception, self‑knowledge, or agency. It does not isolate self-related judgments or agency mechanisms (the role-specific contrasts like leading vs following would be closer), so it does not meet the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self inclusion requirement.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain contrast from healthy adult participants in a social joint‑action task, the contrast (Leading > Conjunction) probes role-based motor/planning and self‑orientation during partnered movement rather than measures of affiliation or attachment. The study does not assess close relationships, attachment styles, or affiliation-specific contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger or explicit cooperation/attachment measures), so it does not meet the ‘affiliation_attachment’ task requirement.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Leading > Conjunction) from healthy adult dancers and indexes role-related self-orientation/agency (Leading involves self-monitoring, action planning and control). It is not an ROI or connectivity analysis nor a between-group comparison, so it meets the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self (agency/self-monitoring) inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants (trained dancers) comparing Leading to other task conditions in a two-person joint-action paradigm. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (talairach peak coordinates) comparing the 'following' role in a joint-action task in healthy adult participants. Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults, the contrast isolates Leading-specific activity (self-oriented motor planning/sequencing) rather than processes of perceiving or understanding another person. The study’s abstract indicates Leading is associated with self-orientation, whereas Following shows sensory/social-cognitive processing—so the Leading > Conjunction contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Others and should be excluded.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast on healthy adult participants, the contrast (Following > Conjunction) comes from a joint-action/motor coordination task (leader/follower dancing) and does not assess affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved‑one vs stranger, kinship, bonding scales). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation or attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants indexing partner-based joint action (following vs conjunction/mutual), i.e. perception/response to another's actions (receptive non‑facial social communication — haptic/proprioceptive cues). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and maps onto the Social Communication construct.

This is a within-subject, whole‑brain voxelwise contrast (peak coordinates/cluster stats reported) from healthy adult participants performing a joint action task. The 'following' condition isolates perception of a partner's actions (action/sensory tracking of another agent), which maps onto the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (Action Perception). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast from healthy adults, the contrast identifies following-specific, externally-oriented activations (somatosensation, proprioception, motion tracking, social/outcome monitoring) rather than processes of self-perception or agency/self-knowledge. The task contrast (Following > Conjunction) does not explicitly measure self-awareness, self-judgment, or agency/self-knowledge required by the "perception_self" construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample (trained dancers) comparing the Mutual joint-action condition to other conditions. The Mutual condition taps social interaction/mentalizing and social reward processes (joint action/partnering), so it meets the social-processing task requirement and none of the exclusion criteria (not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast).

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants contrasting partnered (mutual/joint action) versus non‑partnered conditions. Although this is a whole‑brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes joint improvised movement/physical coupling (motor planning, somatosensation, social cognition) rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., close‑relationship, loved‑one vs stranger, parental/peer bonding). The partnered vs non‑partnered contrast reflects physical joint action, not a measure of affiliation or attachment, so it does not meet the domain inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (Leading + Following + Mutual > Solo + Alone) in healthy adult dancers, comparing partnered (social interaction) versus non-partnered conditions. The task explicitly involves social joint action and taps social-cognitive processes (mentalizing, social reward, interaction), and the analysis is not ROI/ connectivity or a between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Mutual > Conjunction / partnered vs non‑partnered) indexes social interaction, mentalizing, and social reward during joint action rather than processes specifically probing self perception/knowledge or agency. The task/contrast does not target judgments or awareness of the self (self‑knowledge or agency) required for the "perception_self" label, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) contrast from healthy adult participants assessing a social joint-action condition (Mutual) that the paper reports as engaging mentalizing/social-reward systems. The task measures perception/understanding of others (joint action/cooperation), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (partnered vs non-partnered) in healthy adult dancers and probes joint action/cooperative interaction (physical coupling, leading/following), which fits the Social Communication construct (production/reception of non-facial social signals/cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (partnered > non-partnered), which indexes social interaction/cooperation (partnered joint action vs solo). This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants performing joint-action tasks. The contrast indexes social interaction and action perception/understanding of others (leading/following/mutual vs solo/alone), meeting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct and none of the exclusion criteria (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group comparison).

This is a group-level whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants performing a joint/partnered action task. The contrast directly probes social interaction processes (joint action, mentalizing, social reward), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (partnered > non-partnered). The partnered versus solo condition indexes social/ cooperative physical interaction (partnering), which maps onto affiliation-related processes (positive social interaction/cooperation) and therefore meets the task-domain requirement for affiliation/attachment. It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (partnered vs non-partnered: Leading+Following+Mutual > Solo+Alone) indexes social/interaction and sensorimotor aspects of joint action rather than processes of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge. The analysis does not specifically probe self-related judgments or self-monitoring (e.g., leading > following or explicit agency/self-evaluation contrasts), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (partnered > non-partnered) from an interactive joint-action task. This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants, comparing interactive (partnered) versus non-interactive conditions. This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (Leading > Solo) from healthy adult participants performing a dyadic joint-action task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adult participants, the contrast (partnered vs non‑partnered) indexes social/interactional context (physical coupling/joint action) rather than processes specifically probing self-perception, self‑knowledge, or agency. Although the sample and analysis are whole-brain, the contrast (Leading > Solo) indexes role-related motor/planning processes in joint improvisation (self-orientation/leadership) rather than measures of affiliation, attachment, or social bonding. Therefore it does not meet the criterion of a task/contrast assessing affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Leading > Solo) in healthy adult participants. This is a within-subject, whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast (Leading > Solo) in healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults from a joint-action task, the specific contrast (Leading > Solo) indexes self-oriented motor planning/sequencing rather than perception or understanding of another agent. Although the 'Adult' analysis is from a healthy adult within-group inter-subject synchrony (ISC) map, it does not appear to be a task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast explicitly measuring social processing. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of a whole-brain task contrast measuring Social Processing.

This analysis reports within-group inter-subject synchrony (ISC) maps from naturalistic movie viewing in adults, which does not target Perception/Understanding of Self tasks or contrasts (e.g., self vs other, social comparison). This analysis reports within-group inter-subject synchrony (inter-SC) peak coordinates from naturalistic movie viewing in adults. Excluded because the sample is children (4- and 6-year-olds) rather than healthy adult participants required by the inclusion criteria. (Additionally, the reported maps are within-group inter-subject synchrony in a child group rather than a whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults.)

Excluded: the analysis is from a child sample (4- and 6-year-olds), not healthy adults as required. The analysis is from a child sample (4- and 6-year-olds), not healthy adults, and derives from inter-subject synchrony during naturalistic movie viewing rather than a task/contrast measuring Perception and Understanding of Self. Therefore it fails the sample and task inclusion criteria.

Exclude. The analysis comes from a child sample (4- and 6-year-olds), not healthy adults as required. Does not meet inclusion criteria: the analysis is from a naturalistic inter-subject synchrony study in young children (not healthy adult participants), and it uses inter-subject synchrony maps rather than a group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain contrast measuring affiliation/attachment.

This analysis does not meet inclusion criteria. The analysis comes from a study of young children (4- and 6-year-olds) versus adults and reports within-group inter-subject correlation (inter-SC) maps; it is not clearly a whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast from a healthy adult-only sample measuring social processing. Exclude. This is a within-group inter-subject synchrony (ISC) analysis from a naturalistic viewing study including young children (and adults). The analysis is based on child-to-adult inter-subject synchrony in a sample including young children (4–6 y), not a healthy adult-only group. Excluded because the analysis examines child-to-adult inter-subject synchrony and age in a sample including children (developmental comparison) rather than being a whole-brain univariate map from healthy adults only. Does not meet inclusion criteria.
