This is a developmental inter-subject synchrony (child-to-adult inter-SC) analysis across children and adults rather than a group-level univariate task-evoked whole-brain map from healthy adults. It uses inter-subject correlation (a connectivity/synchrony measure) and examines age relationships in a mixed-age sample, so it fails the sample (adult-only) and analysis-type (not univariate task activation) inclusion criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis of studies tagged “social,” not a single-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adults measuring affiliation/attachment. It does not target an affiliation/attachment task contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger) and is a meta-analytic map rather than a group-level univariate task map, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map aggregated across ~1,000 published studies (heterogeneous samples and tasks), not a single-group, task-evoked whole-brain statistical map from a healthy adult sample. It therefore does not meet the requirement that the analysis be a group-level univariate whole-brain map from healthy adults only.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map (clusters from 1,000 studies with the keyword 'social'), not a single-group, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from a healthy adult sample. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a group-level whole-brain contrast generalizable to the healthy population, nor is it a specific task contrast targeting the Social Communication construct. Hence it should be excluded.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analytic map derived from ~1,000 published ‘‘social’’ studies, not a single-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants measuring self-perception. It is neither a primary univariate group-level task map nor specific to the Perception/Understanding of Self construct, and thus fails the sample and whole-brain single-study inclusion criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis map derived from ~1,000 studies keyed to the term 'social', not a single group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring Perception/Understanding of Others. It aggregates heterogeneous tasks and populations and therefore does not meet the required single-study, healthy adult, task-evoked whole-brain inclusion criteria.

This analysis is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis (and ROI confirmation) of general "social" versus non-social images rather than a within-group, whole-brain task contrast specifically targeting affiliation/attachment. It does not test an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation) and the independent confirmation used ROI extraction (ROI analyses are excluded). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, task-related neuroimaging map identifying regions more active for social vs. non-social images (NeuroSynth meta-analysis) and therefore indexes Social Processing. Although it is an automated meta-analytic map rather than a single-study ROI or connectivity analysis, it represents voxelwise, task-evoked effects related to social cognition across studies (predominantly healthy adult samples) and meets the content and analysis-type criteria.

This is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis (term-based map from ~1,000 published studies), not a single-study group-level, task-evoked whole-brain statistical map from a healthy adult sample. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a univariate whole-brain group map generalizable to a healthy control population, and the pooled/meta-analytic nature (and likely mixed subject populations/tasks) further prevents clear mapping to the Social Communication construct.

This map is an automated NeuroSynth meta-analysis across ~1,000 studies, not a group-level, single-study univariate whole-brain task-evoked map from a healthy adult sample measuring Perception/Understanding of Others. It is a meta-analytic, topic-based map (broad 'social' term) that likely includes heterogeneous tasks and populations, so it does not meet the specified sample/analysis inclusion criteria.

This entry reports a NeuroSynth automated meta-analysis map of "social" > non-social images (and ROI follow-up), not a single-study, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample measuring self-related (perception/understanding of self) processes. The contrast reflects general social information (not specifically self-related processes) and the NeuroSynth meta-analytic approach aggregates heterogeneous studies (potentially including non-healthy samples and many task types), so it fails the required whole-brain/healthy-group and task-specific (perception_self) inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI functional connectivity covariate (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). The exclusion criteria explicitly disallow seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI), so it does not meet the 'whole-brain univariate task-evoked' requirement despite involving a social task and healthy adults.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI connectivity covariate analysis (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). The inclusion criteria require group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise maps, while the exclusion criteria explicitly rule out seed-based/effective connectivity analyses. Therefore it should not be included.

This is a seed-based PPI connectivity covariate analysis (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). Exclusion criteria explicitly rule out seed-based/effective connectivity analyses, so it does not meet the whole-brain univariate task-evoked map requirement for the social_communication annotation.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI functional connectivity covariate analysis (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) map measuring perception/understanding of self. Seed-based connectivity/PPI analyses are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This analysis is a seed-based PPI connectivity covariate (controlled PPI − free PPI seeded in right IPL). The inclusion rules require group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps; seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI) are explicitly excluded, so it should not be included.

The contrast Clear > Ambiguous is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate comparison from a healthy adult sample probing perception of communicative intentions (prosody), which is squarely a social-communication/social-processing task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults (Clear > Ambiguous prosody), the task probes perception and categorization of other speakers' communicative intentions (prosody), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes prosodic communicative intentions (criticism, doubt, suggestion) rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measures affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (Clear > Ambiguous) from a study in healthy adults that probes perception/understanding of others' communicative intentions (inferring speaker intent from prosody), which fits the 'perception_others' construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked voxelwise contrast (Ambiguous > Clear) from a study in healthy adults that examines prosodic categorization of communicative intentions (social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes prosodic communicative intentions (criticism, doubt, suggestion) and ambiguity in prosody—not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, love, parental/peer bonding, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content criterion for 'affiliation_attachment.'

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (Ambiguous > Clear) from healthy adult participants performing a prosody categorization task about communicative intentions. The task probes reception of non-facial social communication (vocal prosody/intent), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis—therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level task contrast (Clear > Ambiguous) from a study of healthy adult participants classifying prosodic communicative intentions in speech. It probes reception of non-facial social communication (prosody) and reports whole-brain task-evoked activations (not ROI or connectivity or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a seed-based (Left Amygdala) connectivity analysis, which is explicitly excluded. In addition, the task contrasts (Clear > Ambiguous prosody) probe communicative intention/prosody categorization rather than affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria nor the required whole-brain univariate map requirement.

The analysis is a seed-based (Left Amygdala) connectivity/PPI-style analysis rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map. Seed-based/connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included despite using a social task with healthy adults.

The analysis is a seed-based (Left Amygdala) connectivity/coupling analysis rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. Seed-based/PPI-style analyses are explicitly excluded, so it should not be included despite the task relating to social communication.

This analysis is a seed-based (Left Amygdala) analysis rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map, which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, the task probes perception of others' communicative intentions/prosody (understanding others), not perception/understanding of the self, so it does not match the 'perception_self' construct.

The analysis is a seed-based (Left Amygdala) connectivity/PPI-style analysis rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task activation. Seed-based/connectivity and ROI analyses are excluded, even though the task probes perception/understanding of others.

The analysis is a seed-based (Right Amygdala) connectivity analysis (N=16), not a group-level whole-brain univariate task activation map. Seed/ROI connectivity analyses are excluded by the criteria, so it should not be included despite the social task.

The contrast Ambiguous > Clear comes from a group-level task fMRI study in healthy adults that required categorizing speakers' communicative intentions from prosody (i.e., perceiving/inferring others' intentions). The result appears to be a whole-brain univariate activation contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison) and thus meets the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.

Excluded: this analysis uses a Right Amygdala seed (seed-based connectivity) rather than a group-level whole-brain univariate task activation, and the task (categorizing prosodic communicative intentions: criticism/doubt/suggestion) does not probe affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Both the analysis type and task content fail the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is labeled as a seed-based analysis ('Seed: Right Amygdala'), which indicates a seed/ROI connectivity (e.g., PPI) approach. The inclusion rules exclude ROI/seed-based or connectivity analyses; therefore it does not meet the whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation requirement for the social_communication annotation.

The Ambiguous > Clear contrast probes perception and categorization of others' communicative intentions from prosody (inferring speaker intent), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not target the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This analysis is a seed-based (Right Amygdala) connectivity analysis, which is explicitly excluded (seed/PPI/effective connectivity). In addition, the task probes perception of others' communicative intentions (not self-related processes), and the required evidence is a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation contrast — which this seed connectivity analysis does not provide.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) from 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task. The contrast probes perception/understanding of others' emotions (social processing) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the task probes perception/understanding of others' communicative intentions (fits the domain), this analysis is labeled 'Seed: Right Amygdala', indicating a seed-based connectivity/ROI analysis rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate activation map. Seed-based connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded.

The contrast is from an empathic/emotional-processing task (emotional > neutral video clips) rather than a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure affiliation/attachment per the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (34 healthy participants) and the reported contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (voxelwise clusters reported). The task probes perception/processing of others' emotional/autobiographical video communication (reception of non-facial social communication), so it fits the Social Communication construct. The analysis is not ROI- or connectivity-based nor a between-group comparison.

Healthy adult sample (N=34) and the reported contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrast examining participants' perception/assessment of others' emotional states (empathic accuracy task). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) comes from an empathic accuracy task where participants judge narrators' emotions (perception of others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) univariate comparison in a sample of healthy adult participants viewing autobiographical (social) video clips assessing empathy. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly relates to social processing (empathic tracking/perception of others), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in a healthy adult sample, the task probes empathic accuracy/emotional tracking of autobiographical videos (cognitive and affective empathy). It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation) as required by the annotation. Therefore it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes processing of others' emotional video clips (an empathic accuracy task). The annotation target is Perception and Understanding of Self (self-awareness/self-knowledge/agency). This analysis measures perception of others rather than self-related processing, so it should be excluded.

The contrast is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task activation (healthy adult sample) comparing responses to social stimuli (narrators' autobiographical video clips). The task measures reception of others' emotional state (a form of social communication/receptive non‑facial communication), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (neutral > emotional) from 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic-accuracy task—i.e., perceiving and tracking others' emotional states. The contrast indexes processing of others' emotional/social stimuli and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the "perception and understanding of others" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level analysis in healthy adults (activation correlated with empathic accuracy scores), the task probes empathic accuracy/emotion tracking rather than affiliation or attachment processes (it is not a loved‑one vs stranger or other affiliation/attachment manipulation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This analysis relates BOLD signal to empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) while participants tracked narrators' emotions in videos — a measure of perceiving/understanding others (empathy), not of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a group-level whole-brain analysis on healthy adults, the contrast does not probe perception/understanding of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analysis in 34 healthy adult participants linking BOLD response during an empathic-accuracy (social) task to Z-EA scores (parametric modulation/correlation). It is task-evoked, not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, and measures social processing (perception/understanding of others' emotions), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map in a sample of healthy adults (n=34) using TFCE pFWE thresholding. It indexes neural activity related to empathic accuracy / tracking of others' emotions (receptive social communication—affect recognition from video), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analysis in a sample of healthy adults linking BOLD response to empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) scores — a measure of tracking others' emotions (Understanding Mental States). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in a sample of healthy adults (n=34) examining how BOLD activity covaries with empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) during an empathic-accuracy task. The task measures perception/understanding of others' emotions (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, the contrast indexes empathic accuracy (Z-EA) / emotional intensity tracking rather than affiliation or attachment. The task probes empathy/emotion-tracking with autobiographical videos, not affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the domain requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" annotation.

This analysis indexes empathic accuracy / tracking of others' emotional intensity (Z-EA) during an empathic-accuracy task — i.e., perception of others' emotions (cognitive/affective empathy), not perception or understanding of the self. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, it does not measure self-related processes required for the 'perception_self' label.

The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked result from a sample of healthy adults reporting clusters where BOLD covaries with empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) scores during viewing of autobiographical emotional videos. The task measures perception/tracking of others' emotions (a form of social communication, reception of non‑facial/affective cues). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis tests voxelwise correlations between participants' continuous ratings of another's emotional intensity and BOLD activity during an empathic-accuracy task in a sample of healthy adults (n=34). This is a group-level, task-evoked, whole-brain univariate contrast related to perception/understanding of others (social processing), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The analysis indexes moment-to-moment tracking of others' emotional intensity (empathic accuracy) during viewing of autobiographical videos — a measure of empathy, not affiliation/attachment. Although the sample and analysis appear to be whole-brain in healthy adults, the task does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, bonding), so it does not meet the annotation's task/content inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a healthy adult sample (N=34) that tests a within-group parametric effect (positive correlation with participants' ratings of the narrator's emotional intensity). The task involves perceiving and tracking another person's emotional state (reception of socially relevant, non‑facial communicative information), which falls under Social Communication. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting‑state, or between‑group contrast.

The contrast indexes participants' tracking of narrators' emotional intensity (empathic accuracy) — a perception/understanding of others, not processes of self-awareness or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a sample of healthy adults linking BOLD to empathic-accuracy (Z‑EA) during an empathic-accuracy task (watching/rating others' emotional states). The contrast measures perception/understanding of others and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports voxelwise, group-level correlations between participants' continuous ratings of another person's emotional intensity and brain activity while healthy adult participants watched emotional video clips. It indexes perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathic tracking), is a whole-brain univariate task-evoked result, and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI analysis on healthy adults, the task and contrast index empathic tracking of emotional intensity (empathy/emotional processing). It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved-one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation) or any attachment-related construct, so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise parametric contrast in healthy adult participants (n=34) relating brain activity to continuous ratings of another person's emotional intensity during an empathic-accuracy task. It probes perception/understanding of others (social processing), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This analysis indexes neural responses tracking perceived emotional intensity of another person (empathic accuracy/perception of others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is whole-brain and in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate analysis in a healthy adult sample (n=34) that links neural activity to participants' continuous ratings of others' emotional intensity. The task probes perception of others' emotions (receptive social communication / affect recognition), and the reported maps are not ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a sample of healthy adults linking brain activity to participants' continuous ratings of another person's emotional intensity. The task measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathic accuracy/intensity tracking) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis contrasts person-related/social semantic categories (famous people, social words) versus non-social categories and comes from group-level task fMRI in healthy adults (whole-brain peak coordinates reported). It therefore indexes social processing (perception/understanding of others/social concepts) and meets the inclusion (not ROI or connectivity, not a patient vs control contrast) criteria.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and likely reported group-level whole-brain contrasts, the task contrasts concern semantic knowledge about people versus other categories (famous people, landmarks, abstract social terms) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, bonding or attachment scales). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" annotation.

This analysis contrasts semantic knowledge about famous people (and other social concepts) versus landmarks/other categories — i.e., person- and category-related semantic processing — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although the sample and whole-brain methods likely meet other criteria, the task/contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The contrast targets face-/person-selective responses in the ATL (famous people vs landmarks / face-selective literature), which indexes perception/understanding of others (a social-processing task). The study is on healthy adults and the results are reported as group-level peak coordinates from task-evoked contrasts (i.e., univariate activation peaks), not ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparisons. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This analysis targets face-selective ATL / person recognition (famous people vs landmarks) and reports peak coordinates from face-selective literature, not a task or contrast measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). It also appears to be literature-derived peaks rather than a within-group whole-brain task contrast assessing attachment, so it fails the task/content and whole-brain evidence requirements.

The reported contrast concerns semantic knowledge about famous people (people vs landmarks / social concepts) rather than tasks that probe perception or reasoning about others' current emotional states, traits, intentions, or social interactions. Although the data are from healthy adults and likely come from group-level whole-brain contrasts, the contrast indexes person-related semantic representation (general semantics/face-selective responses) rather than Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., ToM, trait inference, kinship, cooperation), so it does not meet the annotation's construct requirements.

The table entry lists peak MNI coordinates “taken from the general semantics literature and face-selective literature” rather than reporting a group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrast from the study's healthy sample. It appears to be a coordinate/literature compilation (and/or ROI/peak summary) rather than a whole-brain univariate map measuring a social-communication task contrast. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for a group whole-brain task-evoked map measuring Social Communication.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing social (faces + spoken names) to non-social (pictures + spoken landmark names) in a healthy adult sample. It is a univariate task contrast indexing social versus non-social processing (social perception/recognition), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This analysis indexes face-/person-selective responses (famous people vs other categories) rather than processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. The contrasts describe person/face recognition (others), not self-related judgments, and the table reports peak coordinates from the literature rather than a within-group whole-brain task contrast targeting self. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This analysis indexes face-selective responses in the anterior temporal lobe (famous people vs other categories), which maps onto Reception of Facial Communication (facial/face recognition). The contrast comes from within-group task-evoked activations in healthy adult samples (not an ROI or connectivity/between-group contrast), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares person-related (famous faces/names) versus non-social landmarks — a category/face-recognition semantic task — not a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although from a healthy group and likely whole-brain, it does not measure social bonding/attachment constructs required by the annotation.

The contrast compares social (famous people: face + spoken name) versus non-social (landmarks) stimuli, indexing person/social semantic processing rather than self-related perception or self-knowledge. Although likely a healthy group whole-brain contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self (agency or self-knowledge), so it fails the annotation inclusion criterion.

The contrast compares faces + spoken names (person/face recognition) versus non-social landmarks, which probes receptive facial/social information (reception of facial communication). It is a within-group task-evoked contrast in a healthy adult sample (not ROI or connectivity or between-group), and the table reports whole-brain peak coordinates, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The reported "face-selective ATL" peaks come from a semantic/person-knowledge comparison (famous people vs landmarks / face-selective literature) and reflect category/semantic or face-recognition effects rather than tasks explicitly probing perception or understanding of others' mental states, traits, or social interactions. In addition the entry appears to be peak coordinates drawn from the literature (not clearly a group-level whole-brain task contrast mapping social perceptual/mentalizing processes). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's task/content inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast compares non-social landmarks versus social person stimuli (faces/names) to probe semantic/category differences in the ATL, not affiliation/attachment processes. Although likely a group-level task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure attachment, bonding, kinship, cooperation or similar affiliation constructs required by the annotation criteria.

The contrast (social: face + spoken name > non-social: picture + spoken landmark name) is a within-group task-evoked comparison in healthy adults that targets perception/recognition of other people (famous persons) versus non-social objects. This fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (social vs non-social/person perception). The reported peaks imply a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast rather than an ROI/connectivity or between-group analysis.

The contrast compares non-social landmarks versus social (famous) people and probes person/semantic/category differences, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the participant's own self. Although likely a healthy adult, whole-brain group contrast, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast from a healthy adult fMRI study comparing social (famous people/faces + names) and non-social (landmarks) stimuli. Although the reported contrast is non-social > social, it derives from a whole-brain group-level comparison of social versus non-social conditions and thus probes social processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is non-social > social (landmarks > faces/names). Although the task included social stimuli (faces/names), this map identifies regions more active for non-social items and therefore does not index Social Communication processing (it is the reverse contrast). It is a within-group whole-brain fMRI contrast in healthy adults, but because the statistical effect is not measuring greater social-communication-related activity, it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing social stimuli (faces + written names) to non-social stimuli, reported as peak MNI coordinates from a healthy adult sample. It is a univariate task contrast that indexes social processing (person-related perception/knowledge), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast compares social (faces/names) versus non-social stimuli in healthy adults using a group-level task contrast, it does not target affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation/attachment measures). This is a category/person-recognition contrast rather than a measure of social bonding/attachment, so it fails the task/contrast inclusion criterion.

The contrast compares social stimuli (faces + written names) versus non-social controls, which targets reception of facial/person-related communication (a subconstruct of Social Communication). The study uses healthy adult participants and reports group-level voxelwise peaks (whole-brain task-evoked contrast). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares social (faces/names) versus non-social stimuli (i.e., person vs non-person processing), not tasks or contrasts probing self-related processing (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency). Although likely a healthy group whole-brain contrast, it does not target Perception/Understanding of the self, so it fails the annotation inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares social stimuli (faces + written names) versus non-social controls, which indexes perception/knowledge about other people. It is a within-group task-evoked contrast from an fMRI study of (presumably) healthy adults and not an ROI or connectivity analysis, so it meets the whole-brain, healthy-sample, Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.

This contrast compares non-social versus social semantic/category stimuli (people/faces/names) rather than a task probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain, healthy adult group contrast, it does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs and therefore does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is non-social > social (CCp+CCw > face+written name), so it identifies regions more active for non-social stimuli rather than indexing social processing. Although the task involves social stimuli and the sample/analysis appear to meet other requirements (healthy adults, group-level whole-brain univariate), the contrast does not measure engagement of social processing and therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion that the analysis/contrast must measure Social Processing.

The contrast compares semantic/category processing of landmarks (non-social) versus faces/names (famous people) and is aimed at conceptual/semantic representation rather than tasks probing perception or understanding of others' mental states, traits, actions, or social interactions. Although it involves person identity/face recognition, it does not target social-cognitive processes (e.g., mental state reasoning, social comparison, cooperation) required by the "perception_others" construct, so it should be excluded.

The contrast compares non-social versus social category stimuli (faces/names) and targets category-selective semantic/perceptual processing (people vs non-people), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self per the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain comparison in healthy adult participants that directly involves social stimuli (faces and written names), which map onto Reception of Facial Communication. Although the reported contrast is non-social > social, it still measures social-communication processing by comparing social versus non-social conditions. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group contrast in healthy adults (social concept words > non-social abstract words), it indexes general social/semantic knowledge rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). The task contrasts social versus non-social concepts and does not specifically probe bonding/attachment processes required by the "affiliation_attachment" inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares social concept words versus non-social abstract words (semantic/category processing), not a task involving exchange or processing of social communicative signals (e.g., face/affect recognition, interaction, gaze, cooperation). Although participants are likely healthy and the contrast is a group-level task contrast, it does not measure Social Communication per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

The contrast is non-social (CCp + CCw) > social (face + written name), i.e. it isolates regions more active for non-social than social stimuli. Although the task includes social stimuli (faces/names), this particular contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Others (it does not index greater activation for social/other-related processing). Therefore it does not meet the annotation requirement that the contrast measure perception/understanding of others.

This is a within-group task contrast (social concept words > non-social abstract words) from a healthy adult fMRI study that probes social semantic processing. It reports peak voxel coordinates from a group-level univariate contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast examines social concept words versus non-social abstract words (social semantic knowledge), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about the self. Although it appears to be a whole-brain group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, it does not target Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast compares non-social abstract words versus social concept words (semantic/category processing), not a task measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain healthy-adult fMRI contrast, it does not assess attachment/affiliation constructs, so it fails the inclusion criterion.

Although the study used healthy adults and a whole-brain task contrasting social vs non-social word types, this specific contrast (non-social abstract words > social concept words) identifies regions more active for non-social concepts rather than regions indexing social processing. The inclusion rules require the analysis/contrast to measure social processing (e.g., social > non-social or a main effect of social stimuli), so this contrast should be excluded.

Although the sample and contrast come from a standard group fMRI semantic contrast (social-concept words > non-social abstract words), this contrast probes semantic knowledge about social terms rather than a task that operationally measures perception or understanding of others' emotional states, traits, actions, or mental-state reasoning. It does not match the required Perception/Understanding-of-Others task constructs (e.g., kinship scenarios, cooperation, social comparison or explicit mental-state judgments), so it should be excluded.

The contrast (non-social abstract words > social concept words) probes semantic knowledge about social versus non-social concepts rather than tasks of social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchanges). Although conducted in healthy adults with likely whole‑brain fMRI, the task does not measure communicative behavior or processing of communicative signals, so it does not meet the "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares non-social abstract words vs social concept words (semantic/category processing) rather than tasks or contrasts targeting self-related perception/knowledge (agency or self-knowledge). Although likely a healthy-group, whole-brain task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it fails the annotation inclusion criteria.

This contrast isolates semantic processing of non-social abstract words versus social concept words (conceptual/semantic knowledge), not tasks that probe perception or understanding of others (e.g., animacy, action perception, or mental-state attribution). Although it involves social concepts, it is a language/semantic contrast rather than a behavioral/neural measure of perceiving or reasoning about others, so it does not meet the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise F-test across within-subject interaction types during a naturalistic social interaction task in healthy adult volunteers. It reflects task-evoked, whole-brain univariate effects related to social processing (types of non-verbal interactions), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise F-test comparing types of non-verbal social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing in a healthy adult sample (N=16). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The analysis is labeled 'CONTROLS' (healthy control group) and comes from a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain fMRI contrast (FWE-corrected) of participants performing a prisoners' dilemma — a social/neuroeconomic task that directly measures social processing. The analysis is from the healthy control group (adult controls) performing a prisoners' dilemma (a cooperation/competition social task that probes self-related social behaviour). It is reported as a group-level task-evoked whole-brain contrast (FWE-corrected), not an ROI or connectivity or a between-group contrast, so it meets the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a 'main effect of group' from a study comparing frontal lobe epilepsy patients and healthy controls, i.e. it involves a clinical group and a between-group contrast. Inclusion requires whole-brain task maps from healthy adults alone (not comparisons with clinical groups) and excludes between-group contrasts, so this analysis does not meet the criteria.

The analysis is labeled CONTROLS (healthy adult group) and comes from a task using the prisoners' dilemma (cooperation/competition), which maps onto the Social Communication construct. Although the table caption also mentions "all participants," the analysis name indicates this is the healthy control within-group map, so it meets the sample and whole-brain criteria.

The contrast is a 'main effect of group' from a study comparing frontal lobe epilepsy patients and healthy controls, i.e. a between-group analysis including a clinical sample. The analysis is not a healthy-only, within-group whole-brain map. The contrast is labelled as a "main effect of group" and the table caption notes it is an analysis of all participants (15 patients + 15 controls). This contrast indexes action observation (perceiving others' hand kinematics), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). It therefore does not meet the task/content inclusion criterion for the 'affiliation_attachment' annotation.

The contrast indexes action observation / kinematic perception of hand movements, not an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals (facial/gaze/linguistic or cooperative scenarios). This contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes action perception/kinematics, not affiliation or attachment. Although it appears to be a group-level task contrast in healthy subjects, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes perception of others' hand actions (ActionOBS vs CtrlOBS), not processes of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge. Although the study also includes patients, the reported contrast reflects task-evoked activations (PFWE-corrected) for the experimental condition (not a patient vs control comparison), so it meets the sample and analysis inclusion criteria.
